Its not just that though, its like the makers thought hey lets make resident evil matrix style to give it flair, well it doesn't. I don't rate any of the resident evil franchise, i mean the first movie when she's fly kicking a dog, so fake, they should have slowed the pace more and made it more i don't know.........REAL, the video game eats this movie for breakfast, the walking dead eats the whole franchise for breakfast, give me 28 days later anyday. the best part of this whole franchise was the fight with wesker and that was taken from the game itself, what does that tell you?..........EPIC FAIL

review_title: Resident Evil: Retribution blows the last 4 installments out of the water!!!
review_detailed_main:
This installment to the Resident Evil series was simply put.....AMAZING! The action was continually NON-STOP! Was I ever bored throughout one single moment in this movie HELL NO! The visuals were dramatically well done, the 3D was used effectively and the music was fantastic once again for the 5th chapter in the RE franchise.

If you enjoyed the last 4 installments and aren't one of those annoying "It was SO bad because of this and that. I hate this because it ain't like the freakin Capcom games." type of people than you'll enjoy the living daylights out of this film.

From the moment the movie starts the action, the music and the visuals pick up intensity. We rewind through a scene where Alice is fighting the Umbrella Corporation on the Arcada and from there on out the action continues until the very last scene.

I truly have to give 50 thumbs up to Paul on this one. I never felt so entertained and exhilarated after seeing a Resident Evil movie like this one. The last 4 installments were missing something, you know that UMPH! To me this one got it! The fight scenes were incredible and the special effects in every scene were well done. The last scene where Alice has to fight Jill Valentine and where Rain has to fight Leon and Luther was just EPIC.

Did I feel like this movie did its job? YES! Would I go see this again in the theaters over and over YES! Did I enjoy this more than the last 4 installments? Yes sir! I would recommend this film to anyone who enjoyed the last 4 films and has a true interest in the franchise. If you have seen the last 4 films and have some kind of interest in the story of the previous films and of Alice you'll like this film all the much more! So stop reading these reviews and go watch the freakin movie!

review_title: Worst movie of all Resident Evil films...
Decidedly less rubbish than the last few.
review_detailed_main:
The first Resident Evil is one of my all time favourites. Then, unsurprisingly, each film took a step towards utter rubbish.

This offering goes back to its Resident roots and plays out a little more like a computer game.

Like normal, Alice runs and kicks and runs and shoots and takes a good beating. Zombies, mutants and Lycra clad vileness's are never in short supply. The guys who do the bullet-time effects, who I'm sure are paid by the hour, make a killing from this film.

The plot is stupid, the acting and dialogue cheesy. The action predictable and in places monotonous.

BUT saying all that they never intended to remake Citizen Kane here. The premise is set out right from the start in plain English: Alice is here, she needs to get over there, kill a million bad guys along the way, set up for next sequel. The film sticks to this premise rigidly, so really it is your own fault if you carry on watching and are disappointed.

The setting works well and gives a the director a lot of scope to legitimately empty out his box of CGI toys.

The ladies look lovely, the zombies look disgusting and in ninety minutes they get through World War 2's supply of bullets. If this sounds good to you, then happy days!

review_title: Worst movie i forced myself to watch in a while.
review_detailed_main:
As most other reviews have mentioned, this movie is total crap.

The only good thing about this movie is the eye-candy provided by Li Bingbing playing Ada Wong.

I honestly can't believe a professional movie studio approves and funds a piece of crap like this. Resident Evil needs a reboot, with a director (yes, because nobody will convince me this movie actually had a director), a decent plot line that's actually based on the games and WITHOUT MILA.

I'm actually too frustrated to keep on going, so that's all i got to say.

review_title: In 3-D has the diorama apparel and a few thrown implements and viscera for good measure; otherwise missable.
This movie Kills!! RE: Retribution FTW!!
Ada Wong was the best character in the movie (My opinion)
review_detailed_main:
Personally watching the first half of the film I was absolutely bored and on a few certain occasions I almost fell asleep.

The second half was more intriguing when it introduced two characters- Ada Wong and Leon S. Kennedy. The film got immediately more interesting as I was waiting for the two of them to meet up.

Jill Valentine is also one of my favorite characters from the original game but I found her pretty bland in this movie.

Alice felt like an oc (Original character) made by a thirteen year old girl on Wattpad than the actual protagonist of the movie.

As an absolute Ada Wong enthusiast I can say she was done very well in the movie! I love her actor and her dress is an absolute masterpiece (I wish they made merch of it).

In conclusion: The film is bland but it has a few good characters which are worth the watch.

review_title: One of the worst ever Resident Evil sequels
review_detailed_main: I am big-big Resident Evil movie fan. I really expected a lot from this movie; but I am sorry to say this disappointed me thoroughly!! The story was really crappy. Although the action sequences were fine but they were nothing extraordinary. There is nothing new in the movie. Not even at a single point did I feel glued to the movie. After 15-20 minutes into the movie I was really thinking why did I go for it? I think the resident evil series could have done without this sequel. To all those people who have been really waiting to go and watch this movie; well you people can wait for it to come on DVD and have a look then. I don't think this is worth going to a theater for.

Until this point, for all intents and purposes I hadn't seen any of Paul W.S. Anderson's Resident Evil films (I think I saw the first, but don't remember it at all. Were there scary dogs in it?). Entering into a franchise at the fifth installment is probably not the best strategy, but so it was that I found myself sitting down for Resident Evil: Retribution, not entirely sure what to expect. I played a few of the games as a teenager, but again, nothing has really stuck with me. So, how does the movie fare with (essentially) a newcomer such as myself?

Not well. Not well at all.

Thankfully (or so I thought), Anderson opens the film with a lengthy sequence bringing viewers up to speed with the story so far, and surprisingly it seems that the Resident Evil film series has all but evolved past being about zombies. There are a few sequences involving the undead in Retribution, but the real antagonist here is a malevolent artificial intelligence, the Red Queen, who controls the central computer system of the nefarious Umbrella Corporation.

Early on the film is actually pretty fun, and shows potential. Our heroine Alice (Milla Jovovich) finds herself in an Umbrella testing facility, where the Red Queen runs simulations to see how the company's biological weapons affect various cities around the globe. Jovovich, perhaps the only thing holding this series together, fights her way through the Tokyo simulation, culminating in a highly entertaining hallway battle with a dozen zombies.

Unfortunately, it's at this point that Anderson drops Alice into the real story, which I can only assume is continuing from the previous films, as I really didn't understand or care what was happening. As a stand-alone film, Retribution simply doesn't do enough for first-time viewers. What little structure the narrative has never really builds to anything, and it's more or less one long gunfight with an inexplicable rescue mission mixed in. Aside from Jovovich, the acting is atrocious across the board, with particularly shoddy work from Sienna Guillory and Bingbing Li. The performances, and Anderson's direction, are appropriately on par with that of a bad video game cut-scene, and get so bad at times that it almost seems intentional.

Resident Evil: Retribution is not a film for new audiences but for die-hard followers of the franchise, although it's difficult to imagine even the most ardent fans finding much to enjoy here. Jovovich looks terrific and delivers the necessary butt-kicking, but that's really all there is to enjoy. Judging by the conclusion, the inevitable sixth film is probably going to be the last, although so little happens in Retribution that Anderson perhaps should have skipped this story all together and moved on the finish Alice's story sooner.

Side note: I'm no fan of 3-D, but surprisingly Anderson seems to be unafraid to have fun with the format. Although the film suffers from some of the worst light-loss (one of the biggest arguments against 3-D) I can remember, Anderson grabs the gimmick with both hands and is clearly having a blast throwing bullets, axes, and gallons of blood at the audience. The native 3- D (not post-converted) actually makes a difference, and if you must see this movie, then shelling out the extra couple of bucks might be worth it.

tinribs27.wordpress.com

review_title: Somehow manages to be worse than all the others combined

review_detailed_main: I've been a long time fan of the Resident Evil series even when people criticized them left and right. I thought they were really entertaining, stylish and inventive. Until now. There is no way I can stick up for this movie or any reason I'd even want to. I can't really give you a synopsis cause I'm not even sure what I just watched. All I can say is that it was huge disappointment in every facet possible. Despite the silliness of the previous films they always grounded themselves in some type of realism within the reigns of its premise. This entry doesn't even feel like it's a part of the same franchise. Gone is the fun and it's been replaced with ritzy production values and no discernible storyline. It's a movie based on a video game in which they are actually part of a video game and nothing is really happening. Despite a somewhat promising start with a cool reverse battle sequence, a best of franchise film reel and an inventive and even a little scary trip into suburbia we than move on to the supposed purpose of the film which just doesn't make sense at all. I mean the choices are just astoundingly bad why make the little girl deaf and the film filled with sign language, why set it in this underground facility, why is all of this happening, with this type of technology how does the remaining human population even have a chance, how is Wesker alive and why is he good now? he's not human??? None of these questions will be answered and lets not even discuss the frustratingly awkward scenes like one in which one of the good guys has a double unnecessary death, an uninspired nod towards the Alien franchise and repetitive scenarios that get less effective the more you see them (really the squid face things). Also, the acting has never been good in the Resident Evil series but Milla Jovovich had evoked a cool sense of fierce heroine, this time around she just seems plain bored as do the other actors. Filled with insipid dialogue, questionable plotting,overlong pacing, a weird bad movie from the 90's score, mediocre fight choreography (except for the scene with the chain) and a crapload of wasted potential this movie just feels like a bad dream. Sometimes, when I'm really looking forward to a movie I'll dream about it the night before and it will be horrible well this is what this feels like. Because in no possible way, what I just watched is a resident evil movie. Despite all of my complaining the movie does have some decent scenes the suburbia one I brought up before was kinda neat, another featuring Ada and Alice against 2 ax men and the chain fight in Tokyo. Besides that it's all just a big plodding waste of existential cinematic trash. A brainless, soulless unintentionally funny horror/action/sci fi hybrid that despite a larger budget,returning cast members and more impressive production values feels like an overlong filler episode that leaves me with a big question mark. Why has this happened to my beloved franchise???

review_title: More junk from a talentless director
review_detailed_main:
It's pretty amazing that Hollywood keeps throwing money at Paul W. S. Anderson to make films with his wooden wife, Milla Jovovich. RESIDENT EVIL: RETRIBUTION is yet another instalment in the endless franchise, and there are so many of these cookie cutter movies that by now I've lost count of where we are in the series. This follows straight on with the last one and tries for freshness with a few 'virtual reality' scenes of zombie attacks, but for the most part it's just incessant CGI action.

Jovovich has always been poor in these movies; a supposed kick-ass heroine, she continually fails to have any screen presence whatsoever. As she gets older so her body becomes unable to do some of the tougher stunts, so the films get more reliant on CGI as they go on. This one sees Jovovich fighting villains ripped off from SILENT HILL, teaming up and fighting some old faces, and going up against various unstoppable bad guys. It's completely yawn worthy, with nothing we haven't seen before, and I frequently checked my watch, hoping it would all be over soon. Anderson's direction is awful, obsessed with flashy slow motion which looks like a teenage boy was directing.

Realising just how poor and plot less these films have become, Anderson tries desperately to draw in old and new fans alike. So we get a Chinese character (Li Bingbing) for Asian audiences, plus the return of Michelle Rodriguez and Colin Salmon after they died in the first film. Sadly, Salmon only makes a brief cameo, although Rodriguez has more to work with and seems to be the toughest out of all of them. Jovovich is a bore, but her acting is sublime in comparison to the excruciating Sienna Guillory, who gives the most wooden line readings I've ever heard. This is a dud all round.

review_title: There's enough action in here to warrant this pass
review_detailed_main:
(2012) Resident Evil: Retribution SCIENCE FICTION ACTION

One would have to get past a heck a lot of nothing that occurred from the first half hour or so...in order to be fully involved. What is it, it's like the 5th "Resident Evil" movie (not including the computer animated cartoon) starring Milla Jovovich coming back to zombie epidemic that has ravaged the earth. In this one, she wakes up yet again after being unconscious after going into the ocean from an explosion. She wakes up after dreaming about her husband and child, and it turns out that she's in this huge underground dome where hallucinatory images can be created within some buttons. With someone hacking computers to help her escape with at the same time 5 experienced agents sent down below to retrieve her to safety. Lots of action sequences, many of it helped by CGI but does contain some scenes I had never saw before. Written, directed and co-produced by Paul W. S. Anderson, the guy who started the "Resident Evil" movies. Theirs some obvious influencing from the "Underworld" movies.

review_title: Fun and outrageous fifth franchise installment
I enjoyed the first 4 movies but this pretty much killed the franchise
review_detailed_main: Although the Resident Evil movies have always been somewhat disappointing compared to the video games they're based on, I still rather enjoyed watching the first three instalments and, once I made it through the obligatory Kung Fu scene of Afterlife, even that wasn't too bad. So I was really looking forward to Michelle Rodriguez's return in Retribution but, sadly, I was in for a major disappointment. Whereas the first four movies still had something resembling of a story to tie all of the action sense together, it seems like in this one the makers just got together to brainstorm ideas for their new movie but since they couldn't come up with anything good, they just shot every single idea they did come up with, edited them all together and called it a movie. The result is so messy it's hard to believe it was directed by the same man who made Soldier and Event Horizon. In my opinion, as much as the makers of The Walking Dead got the Zombie genre just right, that's how badly Paul W.S. Anderson missed the ball with Resident Evil: Retribution. The ending does leave an interesting opening for a 6th and hopefully final instalment but it's going to be tough to make up for this one.

review_title: If you liked the other RE movies (not just saying you did) you'll love this one
review_detailed_main:
Since I've loved the prior RE films (save maybe #2/Apocalypse), and I thought Retribution was on par or a notch better then #4/Afterlife (which I considered the best to date) I feel I have to give this an Excellent rating.

You have to consider for yourself what camp you're in, before you can digest my rating or this review. Are you in camp that has complained for 10 years now like a broken record that the movies aren't a carbon copy of the video game storyline (which, as I recall, started out as essentially a haunted house type of game)? Are you in the camp that has complained for 10 years now that this isn't a studious courtroom drama? or Are you in the camp that thoroughly enjoys the always-inventive, always-surprising & twisting plot line that Paul W.S. Anderson has consistently brought to screen (either as writer or director, or both as in this one)? If you're in the latter-most camp, I think you'll enjoy Retribution. The budget is higher, the action set-pieces more numerous and over-the-top, the zombies are faster and more-varied, the 3D more in-your-face, and Milla just somehow keeps looking hotter with each film. What's not to love?

Having just seen this in multiplex-theater Imax, I was remarking with my friends that what's really cool about the RE films is how they add something subtle to each movie, which can make you look back on the previous ones in a slightly different viewpoint. Maybe not every plot-point is cleanly 100% covered every time in the series, but I give the film makers an A+ for having gotten to #5 and still having this much energy & purpose (with a #6 obviously being setup). Name another franchise with as much vigor & fun that has arrived at #5, hasn't been rebooted, and is this good.

And to any true RE Movie fan who might be hesitant to see this based on rumors about returning characters who were previously killed-off: rest-assured that it's handled in a cool way which is definitely not the most obvious.

review_title: Loved the previous one this was just OK
I didn't know there were filler movies!
review_detailed_main:
I was very excited when I went to see this movie, the trailer got me hyped up and I was curious how the story would continue!

I will avoid spoilers as much as possible but I can tell you this, you remember that awesome "fight for survival, fortress" - scene from the trailer? Well that one has nothing to do with the movie, its the ending scene!

When I started to watch the Resident Evil movies, i quickly realized, they have not much in common with the games! So you must not try to compare them!

This movie invested a lot in very bad 3d effects that desperately try to cover up the fact that plot and logic went overboard at the very first scene and cruelly drowned!

The story makes absolutely no sense, it completely ignores what happened in the previous movies and the only highlights were some semi nude pictures of Milla Jovovich and well thats it!

The whole plot of this movie is normally covered in the first 30 minutes of any other movie and raises the suspicion that they just want to milk the cow dry!

PREMISE: Alice. Kills stuff. PLOT: Alice. Kills stuff.

Viewers hoping for a coherent narrative are advised to try Capcom's Resident Evil cartoons; viewers completely new to the series really have no choice but to let the images simply break over them like tsunamis. Despite 2 or 3 pages of exposition, series writer/director Paul W. S. Anderson clearly assumes that anyone rejoining him at this point is so familiar with both the movies and the various R.E./BIOHAZARD VGs that new characters (Ada Wong; Leon Kennedy) can be ported over from the games, and old characters (Rain; Carlos) resurrected without explanation (Jill Valentine, Albert Wesker and Luther West are back; Claire and Chris Redfield make cameos). Happily, I AM that geekish, so enjoyed the merry-go-round.

The CGI FX, which are virtually non-stop, are more varied, energetic, and original than in previous sequels. No more mutant dead dogs, thank goodness, although Anderson remains overly-fond of his tentacles- bursting-out-of-the-mouth shots.

The movie is less a script than a series of levels, as Alice, Project Alice, Leon, Ada and their ad hoc teams are dragged through artificial environments adapted from previous installments, from games (notably the new Manhattan and Moscow sets), from any spin-off that isn't bolted to the ground, even from absolutely unconnected franchises (e.g. DAWN OF THE DEAD). Each setting-all controlled by The Red Queen--has its own horde of character clones infected with different strains of the T-Virus and/or Plaga Parasite and its own boss monster adapted from one or another of the games.

If...and only if...that paragraph made the least bit of sense, then this movie's recommended.

review_title: Crapola.... Of the highest order...... Wait for it on TV, then watch the news!
review_detailed_main:
I love the series, all have been entertaining and worth watching, even twice for some of them when repeated on TV, but this has no story, poor script and the acting is rank amateurish. What were the producers thinking, other than fleece the public one last time.

I hope this review saves a few people from wasting there money....

Don't see this, it's a sort of film of a video game, and not very well done even for that....

Don't waste your time on this. Cgi I've read was amazing, I didn't think so, and the gun play and fight scenes seemed illogical and stupid. The enemies fired relentlessly and missed, but the good guys fire a few times and kill dozens?

This review is being written for a very specific purpose. Resident Evil: Retribution actually surprised me! After all, everybody knows what to expect from these movies at this point. The tone shifts from film to film, often the first few minutes of each film destroys the setup from the previous film and then forges onward in a new direction, the acting is generic, the action is stylish and perfectly choreographed to fit the music, etc.

But Retribution feels different. In a way, it seems to be created to be a "greatest hits" merger of the previous films. The video game atmosphere of the first film returns but at this point Alice, Paul WS Anderson and the audience are much further down the rabbit hole, and in gorgeous 3D, no less. The word of the day is "trippy".

The movie begins with the first of many cinematic ballets summing up the end of the last film and then proceeds to what feels like three separate beginnings: a longer recap than we are used to, a scene that feels like a dream sequence, and a self-referential beginning that borrows from the best of the previous films. RE5 feels the most like a video game out of this series and it starts here with a labored outline of the quests and perils to come. The end results is that the first 20 minutes of the movie start to feel like the cut scenes of a video game rather than good storytelling: start disoriented, loot the environment for clothes and equipment, get quest, get map, join party, etc.

The "quest-giver" approach backfires on Anderson, because the set design in this film is absolutely fantastic, and there are an appropriate set of environments and challenges that the characters have to move through in a set time limit (adding to the video game feel). I would have liked to add 'surprises' but there are almost none, because the characters are too well briefed, and so are we as the audience. I realize that it is logical to outline mission parameters in detail, but it does not make for great or suspenseful storytelling, and so Anderson clumsily avoids as many 'WOW moments' as possible which in turn mutes any sense of horror the characters should feel.

The final surprising part of RE:5 is just how bad the dialog is. Child actors put the adults to shame (except Milla), and you can drive a truck through the Shatneresque pauses in the stilted delivery of most characters. I have fond memories of the original Playstation 1 Capcom game for their primitive live-action cutscenes and abysmal acting, but that is not something we need to see recreated on the big screen in the year 2012! The stilted delivery was forgivable in some characters because at least we could rationalize that they were mind-controlled, but really it is a blessing that there is very little speaking and so many many action sequences.

Because after the first 20 minutes or so, RE5 finally kicks into high gear and refuses to downshift. The director milks every opportunity for slow-motion possible, and we are glad of it because each movement looks fantastic. The deadly ballet feel is present throughout the whole film, and is set to what is probably the best score of the 5 Resident Evil movies. The electronica pulses the action along, and an orchestral touch is not overt until the end where it exists to make each punch, bullet, and raised eyebrow feel epic.

For all the movie's flaws, the over-the-top unapologetic action is what we're there to see and Retribution continued to improve in that department. Here's hoping that the next movie capitalizes on Anderson's strengths and turns out to be the orgy of violence that is promised and doesn't try so hard to pretend to have a plot or provide exposition.

P.S.: I have tried to avoid spoilers and instead reference only those characters and events that you might expect if you've seen the other movies. But if you haven't see Retribution yet, here is a fun drinking game you might try: quaff each time you see something that is overtly inspired by or is just plain a rip-off of "Aliens"!

review_title: I saw it first day first show in India... big mistake...
review_detailed_main:
Well I am a die hard fan of the series and was eagerly awaiting this one.

The film is a total waste of time money CGI and talent.. no new twists came up..very little/almost nil plot development.. I just could not connect with any of the characters and in the end frankly did not care if they live or die. The threats also dint seem real.. a single plot carried the whole movie.

All in all BAD.

I will still go to see first day first show of this if there is a next part.

review_title: You was betting on the wrong horse
review_detailed_main:
As a viewer not-familiar with the games of this franchise, I found what I wanted, sexy women action with reasonably fan service outfits in a non-ordinary world. There is also no inconsistency in the story flow of the movies, no matter how cheesy and popcorn it is, that would bother me. In order to attract the audience who loved the movie series, they included the actors of dead characters in the script. And even in this, they have done it properly, in a way that does not disrupt the flow of the movie and is not lazy.

But they also tried to play to game lovers, and this was a decision that was doomed to fail from the beginning. This point is now the 5th movie of the series, 10 years have passed since the first movie. You have created an adapted but irrelevant world of your own, ignoring the atmosphere and ambiance of the games. You can find actors who are very similar to the characters in the game and bring as many of those characters to the screen as you want. You can also refer to them as much as you want. But in this point, at most you can make cheap imitations of them and you won't be able to sell them to game fans. Actually, I can't say that I'm complaining personally. This way, I saw an Asian who got into the action and killed monsters in a sexy local dress.

review_title: Wow... what a piece of trash!
review_detailed_main: I don't even know what to say about this film, because it made no sense, I can't even write any spoilers because it was so jumbled and hard to follow. My concern is why they have decided to release another one of these into a flailing series, which clearly needs to go. Special effects were good, the fight scenes were good but nothing new, so all in all, if you have seen any of the resident evil films already don't bother with this one. This film is what I like to call easily forgotten. Evidently the makers of this clap trap just want to continue the series so they can make a buck or million, because this film was made with no effort, I can't believe that these actors and actresses are no fed up of this by now.

review_title: Good action flick but you'll wish there was a better plot!
Games have better stories than this.
review_detailed_main: Many people compare it to video games (in general), which is wrong because video games these days have much better stories than Resident Evil: Retribution. Personally, I never watched previous Resident Evil movies for story, as shallow as it was.. it was enjoyable, and felt right. In this case, it is awful. In Blu-Ray commentary Paul W.S. Anderson said that "he wanted to keep the franchise fresh", little he knows that this kind of experimentation could actually kill the franchise. And he was not even that innovative, because movie felt (suspiciously) similar to "Sucker Punch". I just hope that producers, and franchise owners read reviews, and next movie will be much better (if they get the financing). They should not even change the director, because Paul W.S. Anderson can direct good movies ("Resident Evil", and "Resurection" were my favorite movies in the franchise).

review_title: Please God make the next one the last one.
More definition of strong action sequences
review_detailed_main:
Apparently this film didn't seem to have much plot as people have highlighted but it's certainly serviceable enough.

As a whole as with its predecessors, this film has the best special effects of the series, top notch looking fight sequences and visually looking monsters, yet this time around the story falls short of expectations. While the other Resident Evil films were executed well as horror and action flicks, this film is somewhat devoid of a plotline that it really plays out like more of a video game.

There were more emphasis on video game structure with its effects. The aspect with Alice's daughter brought a new real life aspect element which showed a new side to Alice.

Bringing back recurring characters in Michelle Rodriguez and Sienna Guillory was a solid decision, despite them being rather bland.

review_title: Resident Evil Enters the Schumacher Era

review_detailed_main:
My first encounter with the Resident Evil franchise was some years ago when I saw a chunk of "Afterlife" (the fourth in the series) on TV, and really enjoyed it. So when I saw the whole franchise was available on Prime (albeit for an extra fee), I jumped at the chance to watch them all.

Well, it turns out that the first three movies in the series aren't up to the standard of Afterlife. But after watching the latter again, it pretty much lived up to my positive memory of it, and made me look forward to the next in the series - the subject of this review - Retribution. And I have to say I was disappointed. Because if the first three movies were kind of silly, Retribution is silliness on steroids.

It's not hard to figure out what happened with Retribution. Basically, the creators of the series must have sat around and said to one another "what can we do to top what we have already done?" And their answer was: "Action! More action than ever before! Nonstop action from start to finish!" But something else clearly occurred: the creators ceased to take their creation seriously. I guess after doing four consecutive Resident Evil movies,they must have been getting pretty tired of the whole concept.

So what you have in this movie is action - lots and lots of it - but ludicrous, cartoonish action. How cartoonish? Just one example: in one scene, a bad guy shoots a bullet at one of the heroines, she sees the bullet coming, so she points her machinegun vertically downwards, cuts a 360 degree hole around her feet with the bullets, and then drops down through the hole in the floorboards before the bad guy's bullet can hit her! So now you know what you are in for with this movie.

Having said that, it's not all bad. The production values are high. Milla Jovovich is always watchable. And once you accept the premise that you are watching a live-action fantasy where almost anything is possible, the movie is kind of enjoyable on its own terms as a sort of pure action romp. It's just a shame that they couldn't build on the intrigue hinted at in the previous movie. Still, I'm giving it a six for the sheer nutty exuberance of the thing and the laughs.

review_title: too much show-off on action, lack of the essence of Zombie movie
review_detailed_main:
First, the story should align up with the original game Resident Evil. The movie has its own plot different from the games, but that is OK - still acceptable. Ever since the first Resident Evil movie, the story has gone too far. The 2nd Resident Evil movie was better than the 3rd, 4th, this 5th. The last 3 Resident Evil movies are lack of good story, only full of actions but meaningless fighting. Without zombie, the movie could be recognized "pure action movie without purpose".

Disappointed but not surprised by this 5th Resident Evil movie. It is still pointless, lack of story, only with show-off actions.

I rate it 6 for its "not bad" graphics

review_title: Poor Acting, Rips Off 'Aliens', and Time for a Series Reboot With A New Director
Its not supposed to be Shawshank Redemption !!
review_detailed_main: I think one thing that has plagued the RE movies and any video game movies that get made for that matter is the fact that people will go to see them who have no prior knowledge of the games and what RE universe entails. Yes the film has cheesy moments and the acting isn't on a level with say Marlon Brando but honestly who cares !?!? This like all the other RE movies are kick-ass rides involving loads of guns ! beautiful women ! zombies and monsters ! I knew exactly what to expect with RE:R and I loved it, and its my film of the year ! and yes I saw the Dark Knight..10/10 isn't exactly what I would score the movie (more like 8-9) but I think there's so many morbid people out there that score films like this so low its unfair. I look forward to the next RE movie ! now back to playing RE6.. :)

review_title: I enjoyed it! Even if it was terrible!

review_detailed_main: If you want a movie to feel exactly like a video game, this movie is for you because that's exactly how it feels. I've never seen a movie that felt more like a video game in my life. However, if you're like me and you want your movie to have plots that actually make sense and have a nice flow to them, you probably won't enjoy this movie. It's really upsetting that a franchise that started so well has disintegrated into this. The first two films, I thought were outstanding but the next two were plagued with absurd levels of ridiculousness and this film had the worst plot development I've seen yet. It's unfortunate too because the acting is good enough and the action sequences are entertaining but the cheesy 3D elements and the garbage plot development show just how a terrible director can destroy a movie. I'm glad they're only making one more... though, how they made this many just shows how stupid Europeans actually are.

Although I've seen worse movies, (not many, but they're out there), and this MAY not have been as bad as the last, it was still yet another complete let down by the Resident Evil writers. These movies veered TOTALLY off course, and shouldn't even be considered part of the Resident Evil movie selection. Not to mention, VERY short. Just when you think it's about to begin, it ends. I'm legitimately mad at myself for paying to see this. I keep "hoping" that maybe the writers will come out will a truly well-put-together movie, or even just better than the last, but have severely failed my expectations for the last handful of movies. If they do plan on coming out with yet another Resident Evil, which is definitely suggested by the total LACK of movie, I, for one, will not be donating my money again.

review_title: This is not a movie, this is a video game
review_detailed_main:
There is not much to be said about this movie. Even the most optimistic viewers wouldn't expect anything more from this than another zombie flick full of running, jumping, fighting, shooting, infinite amounts of bullets being fired, a little gore, and a shallow plot.

As a horror, it's a disappointment; but to be honest, can you really expect to be frightened by a movie that you've seen four times already (this being the 5th sequel, and all of them are practically identical)? As a sequel to the franchise - yes, I must agree that this one is probably the worst and least amusing of all five movies, but that doesn't come as a surprise, because with this type of movies it's always the same, each new sequel is worse than the one before.

But all of this didn't come as a surprise to me, and to be frank, this movie didn't disappoint me personally, in any aspect, because my expectations weren't that high anyway. It may have been done better, of course (there is always room for improvement), but I don't mind, really.

There were numerous hilariously illogical "mistakes" in the movie (as one might call them), but I don't consider them as mistakes, as such "mistakes" happen in all R.E. movies and since all the movies are based on a video game (and we all know how video games can be). If this were an independent movie, I would totally trash it, but while watching it, I kept thinking to myself that I was actually playing a PC game, and of course you can expect that, for example, in a game a character runs through a rain of bullets and comes out unharmed. Because such games are essentially not about the story and logic, but more about the adrenaline. Though this raises a dilemma - why would anyone keep creating such movies, when we HAVE video games, and they serve better for that purpose? The answer is simple enough - to raise some more money living on old glory. The first movie was legendary, and the sequel to it was expected and welcomed - everything else was pretty much the same - mediocre and rather poor.

I sincerely hope this one will be the last sequel of this franchise, just for the sake of keeping dignity of the original story. But, if they do make another one, I'll most probably watch it anyway.

review_title: Paul W.S. Anderson, the living T-Virus for intelligent filmmaking.
Finally saw this one, probably one of the better entries...

review_detailed_main:
This 4th sequel is absolute rubbish. If I watched it in the cinemas, you can be sure that I'd have walked out after 10 minutes to get my money back. It is that bad. You don't have to watch much to know how excruciatingly horrible this movie is. I can't believe how they even got the money to produce it or who was stupid enough to blindly put money into this.

Milla Jovovich is at her worst but this is only normal. At first I thought she lost weight but it was just the long hair. With the tom-boy hair, she looks fatter. Her acting is not up to scratch at all, actually you can plot a graph of her gradual worsening from the 1st movie to this one (rock bottom). Most of the action scenes make no sense and produce the yawnies. I'm not going to elaborate. Stay away from this pile of fecal matter. I wouldn't watch it or stream it even if it were free.

Loved the movie it was awesome cant wait for the next one this movie was worth my money loved it Alice was great n she was hot zombies looked sickkkkkkkk overall I give this movie 10 stars because it was that good best resident evil movie lots of action!!! If I could give this movie 100 stars I would it all the all the actors looked like the actual characters from the game Michelle Rodriguez is a really good actor I was really happy when they brought her back I like how the zombies weren't slow looking the evolved lol they look all crazy now but it's cool because I'm tired of watching slow looking zombies great great great movieeeeeeeeere u should definitely go watch it u won't regret it unless ur like 50 or something ;))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))) I hope they make the 6th one!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

review_title: Resident Evil Retribution is just a Time Pass film in Resident Evil Film Series, but nothing more.

review_detailed_main:
The Resident Evil franchise has been good to me. In this review I can only voice my own interest in the franchise, I should also note that the Resident Evil series should not be seen as films, but as mere products to help sell the next video game. That is of no consequence to me, I understand what to expect before I pay for my ticket, and I've known what to expect ever since I paid to see Resident Evil: Apocalypse.

I have been a loyal fan of the series since its inception, and I managed to see the first movie on DVD when I was about 14 years old. At first I didn't think the movie was good, I thought it was disgraceful. But, gradually the first Resident Evil movie became my guilty pleasure. I've somehow learned not to pay attention to the storyline, because there is none, you won't find a storyline in the Resident Evil movies, they purely stand on their own, and the only thing that holds them is its leading lady, Milla Jovovich. The reason for such an ambiguous approach is that more sequels could be milked until people get sick of them.

Here's what I love about Retribution, and all those other movies that came before it. Two words. Milla Jovovich. Milla Jovovich is an iconic and legendary figure in the action genre. Just like Greta Garbo was queen of the silent era, and Bette Davis the queen of the talking picture, Milla Jovovich owns the action genre. There is never a dull moment when Milla Jovovuch is kicking ass, shooting her weapons in glorious slow motion, and not to mention her high-flying kicks.

This babe is what has transcended the entire Resident Evil series into art. Yes, I said ART. The art of ass-kicking has never looked so good with Milla in her tight spandex, blazing sub-machine-guns in 3D. If you want a reason to watch this movie, then there it is. Paul W.S. Anderson is no hack either, he's interesting as an action director, more so than abysmal hacks like Luc Besson, even more so than Robert Rodriguez. I also love his futuristic set piece, you must admit that they are very creative. As long as Milla Jovovich stars in these movies, they can count on my 15 bucks to watch her.

For those complaining about the movies not being like the games, you try and a adapt a video game into a movie! To make a film out of a video game, you need to recreate the entire thing, because all you do in the games is solve puzzles and shoot at zombies for countless hours. How can you make any kind of cinema out of that? It's impossible. It;s like trying to drive a car without an engine, you have a good looking body, but no engine to make it go. And that's what Resident Evil games are in a nutshell, they look good and scary - but that's about it.

review_title: The only evil in this sequel
Don't waste your time or be ready for disappointment
review_detailed_main:
I have enjoyed all of the previous movies, some more than others but this movie was absolutely flabbergastingly horrible! They spent way way too much time on action scenes and there was very little story. I agree with another reviewer that the whole movie felt like an opening scene. I literally checked the time into the movie at one point and it was 1hr 10 min and i thought to myself, well there is still 50 minutes to round this out and give us a story. And then the movie ended....

Like another reviewer said, the whole movie could have been condensed to 20 minutes and they could have given us more to the story. It is disgusting that they would drag this out just so they can add another sequel in this franchise.

There is little plot, little dialog and really not much mentionable about the movie. I wish i could demand my money back!

It's the most action-packed entry of the series so far and a fun one.

The folks who have been wanting to witness Alice and her quirky confidantes kicking more butts and splattering more guts would treasure this glorious bloodfest! However, those who were hoping to get a meaningful expansion of the narrative may feel cheated and misinformed!

It's either going to sit right with the audience or not; there's no in-between. As far as my assessment is concerned, I liked it, and I surprisingly had a good time with the film, contrary to my expectations.

P. S. The opening reverse Slo-mo sequence looked fantastic and was so well choreographed!

So disappointed...have been a fan of the Resident Evil movies since the first one but found 'retribution' just a mishmash of all the previous movies and I had a problem getting my head around the plot.

There was no final and positive outcome to the series... I had to of course, watch it and only scoring as I have, because I am a huge fan of Milla.

I think producers and directors ran out of ideas of how to finish the 'resident evil' series but gave no clear ending to them.

Such a shame but if you are a 'resident evil' fan then you had to make the effort to see it, but the 'die hard fans' will be terribly disappointed.

review_title: Can't wait for the next one!!
review_detailed_main:
I usually don't pay much attention to the reviews on IMDb because they seem to be written by wannabe film school students and not basic public movie watchers. After seeing all the horrid reviews I had to speak up.

Finally a video game movie that feels like your watching a video game. The first four "Resident Evil" movies were more of a traditional type (A story inspired by characters and events from a video game). This one goes a different route and is more like watching an automated video game with the characters of the previous movies.

I don't need complicated plot lines, character arcs or a believable story to be entertained. Personally, I could watch Alice (Milla Jovovich), Jill Valentine (Sienna Guillory), Rain (Michelle Rodriguez) & Ada Wong (Bingbing Li) kick butt video game style for 12 hours straight. But maybe that's just me. I'm the kind of guy that watches an entire season of "24" on my one day off.

I own the first four "Resident Evil" DVDs and after renting "Retribution" I'll be buying it too.

I'll sum it it with the fact that I really enjoyed this movie. No, the movie isn't thought provoking, a social commentary or an exploration into the human psyche. It just get's Alice through another day.

review_title: I bet you've seen this before ...
review_detailed_main:
Five films in and these things just keep getting better and better and better ... and I'm lying. They are actually almost exactly the same (the only difference is a recurring castmate who might return for every other film to help Alice).

Once again Alice (Milla Jovovich - The Fifth Element, Ultraviolet) finds herself in trouble at the hands of the Umbrella Corporation who has (again) developed lethal killing machines/beings/plagues that want to wreak havoc on the remains of humanity (after the first Resident Evil movie over ten years ago). This film is nearly as braindead as the Umbrella-engineered zombies found in the film's first half.

The film is so bad that during a zombie attack scene, I asked myself why nobody on the streets fleeing had carried a black umbrella ... they were a multitude of colors with nary a black one in sight. It doesn't matter at all ... but neither does the film.

If one wants to continue the tales of Alice, by all means watch this one; but you've seen this before. The entire premise of this fifth film is Alice escaping from a training facility and so every door she enters is simply a new scenario -- that is it. Yawn ... it is always more of the same! No wonder I was so intrigued by black umbrellas.

review_title: It has "cheap" written all over it.

review_detailed_main:
This is the absolute worst of all the resident evil movies. There's no red line, the storyline is crap and it reminds more or less of a bad video game. Mindless quotes, seen-that-done-that action scenes, bad acting and a completely messed up plot is what you get. Take for instance the start where the previous film left you, on the boat about to being attacked by the umbrella corp. That's pretty much where you are left story wise throughout the film. I watched it because I've seen the others and had a hope of something more about the story behind umbrella

This is one of those films, where you are better off taking a walk or counting matches.

review_detailed_main: Resident Evil, the first one was the best and till 4 it was still OK to watch, just watch. BUT Retribution was the worst thing I have ever seen in my life! Really, I normally don't critic any movie but this was pure bull manure! No story, no plot, nothing totally NOTHING, just gun shooting in pure nothingness! This was the worst movie I have ever seen in my life and I love Resident Evil from game to movie!! Really sorry! But WOW! Never thought this would be like that! They could have made anything after RE 4 but this... there are really no words to explain how bad all of this movie is! Capcom, you should sue the director because he and the whole crew have destroyed the whole name of Resident Evil, destroyed everything in the name of Resident Evil and Umbrella corp. THIS WAS PURE AWFULNESS!!! Can't believe people gave it even a 5 or 6 in stars! This was totally -10 not 1. INCREDIBLE!

This movie was made for 2 reasons and 2 reasons only... to squeeze a few more dollars out of a very tired franchise, and to cash in on the ridiculous 3D craze that's been inexplicably sweeping globe. Few things annoy me more than scenes that are in a movie for the sole purpose of showing off a 3D effect, and this movie is chock full of them (a distant second to The Harold & Kumar Christmas movie however, which was shot almost entirely for the purpose of dazzling the audience with pointless 3D effects).

The movie was almost entirely devoid of a script or plot, the writing was amateurish, and the acting matched the writing. There's no emotional investment in whether a character lives or dies anymore, because at this point in the franchise characters can be resurrected and interchangeably turned into a good or bad guy, or in some cases the characters can't die at all. You don't have to worry about zombies infecting people, because now there are cures for the T-Cell virus as we saw from the previous movie, and they can simply re-infect people when they want.

If you're a die hard Res Evil fan you probably don't care about any of that and will enjoy the movie, but if, like me, you enjoyed the first movie but felt that they've just been getting worse and worse with each successive sequel, then I suggest you spend your time doing or watching almost anything else. The good news is that this short 95 minute movie is actually only 84 minutes long, with an almost record setting 11 minutes of credits. Amazing for a movie that only has about a dozen roles with any spoken lines. Probably 10 of those 11 minutes are dedicated to those responsible for the special effects and CGI. My suggestion is to skip to the last minute or so of the movie, which just sets up the next crappy sequel, since it's probably the best scene of the entire flick (and that isn't saying much).

I understand what all the hate for this movie is all about. But for the heck of everything I loved the movie. I watched this with my family expecting absolutely nothing! I mean come on RE does not really pride itself with witty one-liners or insane plot twists. Its a simple story about a bad corporation who wanted EVERYTHING! Even if it meant eradicating the human race then comes our heroine Alice who never dies (which I find cool and silly at the same time) and fights this corporation GUNS FREAKING BLAZING!

By this time, I am pretty sure you know how the story goes and how future sequels will go through with this (which I am sure there will be MORE)unless some outlandishly good and creative writer and/or director comes in to play and decides to revamp this series (I will welcome that person with open arms hopeful that with a new approach the old action scenes are kept with the same intensity)

Acting is okay... I mean what do you expect? HELLO?? Get out of your hole for one minute and just enjoy! The actors were just full of bad- assery I didn't mind it that much that none of those performances were in the levels of Meryl Street or Philip Seymour Hoffman but still it complimented the show's playfulness and brute.

Story - mentioned this before already, ITS A NO-BRAINER!

WORD TO THE "SERIOUS" CRITICS: Stop being to harsh on this film. It wasn't made to satisfy your insatiable longing for the next Slumdog Millionaire and frankly, I don't think they care much about what you say. They just shoot some zombies, monsters, etc. and just have some damn fun with it! If you want a morally upheaving movie don't watch this. It will not get you anywhere.

FINAL NOTE: I gave this a 9 not because of its story, acting, or anything that I would consider if I am seriously critiquing this movie but my rating is based on how much I enjoyed myself and not once did I yawn or even lean on the back of my chair it was a fun ride and I wouldn't mind watching RE6.

Rented from Redbox, and struggled to finished the movie. I am not a RE fan but have seen the previous four. While none of them are Oscar contenders, generally it is good for 2 hours of action adventure, millions of rounds of bad shooting, zombies and generally watchable.

Oh wow. Whether you are a fan, semi-fan, or even a hater, this movie is such a step down from any of the previous four.

Mistake #1 Everything was done in one warehouse, one cul-de-sac of houses, and a whole bunch of computers. I doubt very seriously if Milla Jovovich even had to leave the same room for 85% of the movie. I would not surprised me if all her scenes were done in a couple days, and the computers did the rest. There was no need for costume designers, stunt people, stunt cars, or even makeup people, everything was CGI, including the bruises on the face.

Mistake #2 The guys that essentially did all the CGI, also wrote the dialogue. The conversations are on par with the dialogue in a bad porn movie. You will have a hard time finding a conversation involving more than 20 words...total...for both people.

In short, this is the world's best movie done with Photoshop, or you could say it would be the winning entry of a movie composed by film students(first year community college students). But for a movie that people pay money for, it was almost as if the producers/directors were purposely trying to find the minimum effort needed to stamp the 'Resident Evil' nameplate to. It would have been better if they advertised it as a comedy.

review_title: Easily the WORST of the series!
Chix Chat on Film Review: Alice versus Umbrella Corp again.
review_detailed_main: Resident Evil is the next tale of Project Alice (Milla Jovovich) and it picks up at the point where Afterlife left off, with the released passengers afloat on the Arcadia. The opening scenes were very cleverly shot, and this film has some crisp and impressive CGI. I saw it in 3-D so I will admit that I flinched more than once when things came flying off the screen at me or a zombie seemed to get up close and personal. For those who are not particularly familiar with the series, this film gives a complete synopsis of what has transpired in the previous films from the very beginning up to the current circumstances. Anyone looking for a high body count, loads of action and a hodge-podge of nonsense should see this film. The trailer shows that some of the original characters have returned in this installment and I wanted to see how it was done, since I had personally seen the demise of Rain (Michelle Rodriguez) and others in the first film. Then I thought 'duh', if they can have an inventory of Alice then Umbrella Corp can have a bunch of anyone and everyone. One of those nonsense moments that I mentioned was when Rain first shows up on screen and I thought, if you are trying to escape zombies why would you have your windows open? There were so many other WTF moments, but hey it's based on a video game it doesn't have to make sense, says the woman who at a time frequently played Frogger. The fact that this story originated from a video game was oh so obvious this time around. Almost every scene was reminiscent of being in an arcade standing behind your best friend who has mastered the game and continues to survive through to the next level. The problem is that you quickly bore with cheering your friend on a want some action for yourself. Even with all the acrobatic fights, the mutants, the zombies and the big banging explosions, there were moments when I keep thinking 'how much longer'? The climatic fight scene wasn't even that climatic with Alice squaring off against Jill Valentine (Sienna Guillory). It was too drawn out for my taste and in the end she did exactly what I was thinking should have been the first defensive move. I am giving this film an amber light, and the only reason it's not a red light is Boris Kodjoe (Luther West).

review_title: The zombie apocalypse just got boring.
review_detailed_main:
You go into a RESIDENT EVIL film thinking you know exactly what you're getting. A statuesque beauty kicking undead ass while attempting to uncover an overarching corporate/government conspiracy, and also while saving the lives of assorted, improbably well-coiffed, survivors of the zombie apocalypse. There'll be impressive feats of insane bravery, a whole bunch of wire work, slow motion replays of previous events, assorted sidekick types lost and found, the occasional fright provided by the lurking legions of the undead, and lots and lots of gunfire, all scored to a calculatedly pounding baseline you can feel all the way to your spine.

You're not expecting high art, not for a second. But neither are you, I would hazard a guess, expecting to be bored.

From the outset of this, the fifth in the franchise, that was my predominant emotion. Oh, I jumped a little every now and then at the advance of a particularly heinous zombie horde, I was able to call forth at least a modicum of appreciation for the continuing splendor of the action sequences, and there was more than a little perplexity in there as well as the tale got ever more convoluted, but almost from the moment our heroine, Alice (Milla Jovovich) began her usual deadpan recounting of previous events, her "My name is Alice, and I'm about to exposition the hell out of you people" straight-to-camera Story So Far, it was all I could do to muster any interest in proceedings.

This is a shame, as there is not a single other entry in the series that I didn't, at least on some level, enjoy. Perhaps my major problem with this movie is that it is by far the most video game-esque of all of the series thus far, and since I have never played the game, I don't really understand these scenes' appeal. Director Paul W. S. Anderson has dispensed with even the semblance of plot now, and instead is relying on the thrill of vicarious levelling up to appease moviegoers. Oh, there has always been an element of this in the movies, as is only right and proper; one should never ignore one's roots, and not throwing in the occasional sop to the gamers in the form of a subtle reference to one of the more beloved design elements would be not only disrespectful but foolish. But there is subtle homage and then there is outright cinematic LARPing; Jovovich and co. basically spend the majority of the movie as live-action Player 1, working their way through level after level, all the while shooting almost indiscriminately and surely taking hits that should have killed, or at least inconvenienced, them in all of the chaos. I swear, I saw the guy beside me in the theater flick his fingers in what looked very like someone mastering a PlayStation controller, his sense memory clearly telling him that for all of this stylized, almost ritualistic carnage to be erupting on screen in front of him then surely he should be X-Y-bumper-right-left-ing to make it happen.

The premise is this: picking up directly from where the last movie left off – and yet, not entirely – Alice is captured by the ruthless Umbrella Corporation and is due for extermination by the rogue company artificial intelligence, the Red Queen. She experiences a memory, or perhaps an hallucination, where she was married to Oded Fehr and had a hearing impaired daughter before the zombies took over the world, and when she awakens in her cell, it takes her a moment to recapture her badass. Capital-E EVIL corporate lackey Albert Wesker (Shawn Roberts) frees her from her cage for inscrutable reasons (he tries to explain, but his stentorian, Agent-Smith-"Mr. Anderson"-style delivery of his every line makes it hard to focus), and then Alice and her wooden, if dexterous, new helpmeet Ada (Li Bingbing) must battle their way through the Umbrella complex, defeating the antagonists in each new room – and, of course, the hard-to-kill Big Boss – before moving on in an attempt to escape. Oh, there are other people involved here, too; some from previous movies in the franchise, some new faces, but the main objective is just to kill as many extras as possible, be they zombie or Umbrella minion or clone.

I may be making it sound more interesting than it actually is.

Then there are the performances. Milla Jovovich does her valiant best, but this is a hard plot to rise above, and it is really only when she is sharing the screen with the most abysmal of actors – and there are many – that she truly shines, if only by comparison. Michelle Rodriguez, who is way too good for this, is fine, considering the few scenes and limited dialogue she has to work with, and Oded Fehr, whom we see in this one for barely a second, is WAY too good for this, and must have really needed the paycheck -- but then, he was way too good for APOCALYPSE and EXTINCTION, and they were exponentially better films.

Most of the remainder of the speaking cast – excepting the aforementioned Roberts and Bingbing – are fairly inoffensive, and Boris Kodjoe always brings the pretty, but Sienna Guillory as friend-turned- Umbrella-puppet Jill is truly terrible, going for possessed-by- malevolent-artificial-intelligence but achieving only petulant, I-was- rejected-from-THE HILLS screechiness.

The movie ends on a cliffhanger (as has become the norm in this franchise), and for the first time I just don't care at all what happens next. So perhaps I should be happy, now cured of one of my more pointless enthusiasms of recent years. And should a sixth movie in this series be made, as seems unhappily likely, here's hoping the zombies win.

– Rachel Hyland, Geek Speak Magazine

review_title: If you haven't enjoyed any of the other movies this movie is certainly not going to change your mind
review_detailed_main:
The Resident Evil franchise began in 2002 and has been pumping out sequels ever since. The mastermind behind this series is none other than Paul W.S. Anderson who has had an incredibly spotty career as a director with only a couple of films being solid. While the first Resident Evil was a solid B- movie, the series has gotten gradually dumber and more ridiculous with each passing film in the franchise. While the series has never been known for its high quality of film making, they have been more or less a fun way to pass the time. Does Retribution do anything to excite the series or is this fifth entree three too many?

review_title: While I did not enjoy this one quite as much as the previous three, I still enjoyed it
review_detailed_main:
I need to hang my head in shame for enjoying this film as much as I did as I can see by the score here that most people did not care for it. However, I did enjoy it...I thought it was a fun, fast and action packed movie. It did not overstay its welcome and had a lot of fun within. Milla is back and she does what she usually does in these films, kick a lot of butt. Also back are a few old friends...I saw their names in the cast and I was unsure how some of them would come back, but I thought they did a good enough job reintroducing them.

Alice has been caught by umbrella as she has to once again escape one bizarre installation. She receives help from the mysterious Ada Wong and from another surprising source. They must battle their way out of an underground hive facility in Russia...this facility being so huge it has areas that look like a Tokyo street, a suburban environment and a Russian area too. A group of mercenaries has also been commissioned to help the two girls out. So prepare for lots of action and lots of zombies and of course lots of wtf creatures too.

The Resident Evil films, to me, are like those old serials of the 30's, 40's and 50's. Do not take it too seriously and sit back and enjoy the show. Heck, most of the films of this series are an hour and 30 minutes usually so they are short and do not take forever to get started and have no sections where nothing is happening. You get your surprising revelations, that you know could not be possible, but that is the fun of it. You start looking for plot flaws and of course you are going to find them, just like the old serials of yesteryear. I also enjoy how they pick up where the last film leaves off, and for a series with a relatively low budget compared to other films, at least they can keep bringing back the same actors and actresses to play the parts...'cough' Batman 'cough, cough'.

So yes, I enjoyed this film quite a bit. At times I do feel the series relies to much on computer generated effects, but so do most movies these days. I kind of wish they would go back to making monster effects using rubber and stuff found in a normal household. While I did enjoy the film a lot, I did not like it as much as part two, three and four. I do hope they make another one, but it should be the last one...period. Have a conclusion as sooner or later these things are going to stop making enough money to justify a sequel, and it would be so annoying for the series to stop and leave those of us who enjoy it hanging.

This installment of the Resident Evil series takes the convoluted story of the first four movies and throws it out the window, to replace it with an even more nonsensical story. I have no idea any more who is whom, why characters do what they do and what the point is. Still, lots of shooting, fights and explosions. That's good at least.

OK, firstly. I'm a huge fan of resident evil/flesh eating zombie films. I've seen every resident evil film and was a fan ever since. This one wasn't all that, but I can see where the creator(s) of this film are coming from. Watching the ending of this film it's clearly seen that they've encountered A lot of mutated zombies behind a wall, this MAYBE proves that there's gonna be a new resident evil film in the future? (HOPE SO) And yes, many say "what ever happened to good old zombie horror films". But listen, resident evil is coming towards a new era of zombie's, and I'd like to see that. I had to seriously, watch the film twice to understand it, but I can clearly see that their aiming towards more SCI-FI stuff mix with zombies? which i'm totally fine with. I just hope they make another resident evil to back this one up otherwise it's pretty disappointing. If they end up making another one, would be awesome if they called it ' Resident Evil: The New Era ' or Resident Evil: The Beginning Of The End', something like that to get the fans interested again.

This film is definitely the weakest of the franchise so far.

The story was really quite weak, and I just couldn't get on board with it at all. I enjoyed that they brought back a few of the cooler characters from the franchise, but they all felt very hollow, there for show and shock value rather than for any real meaning or contribution to the plot.

In terms of the dialogue and acting, Retribution falls below the already relatively low standard set by the rest of the franchise.

On the bright side I did enjoy the action in parts. There were a few generic bits that were going through the motions, but mostly it was fun. Hopefully, based on the final scene, we are now set up for an action packed sequel.

This is a necessary watch as part of the franchise, but it definitely feels like a chore at times.
I don't know what's the point of this chapter, it was like a big video game... Action, action, action and no story whatsoever. Pls skip this one because the.final chapter is awesome!

review_detailed_main:
5 out of 5 stars

Retribution packs a non stop, intense movie. It continues after the last movie. The plot is good. It packs with a wild and confusing beginning. But it all makes sense mins later. The movie is one wild thrill ride. Which it never slows down with the action. The movie moved very fast with each action set pieces. Paul Anderson script and direction made this movie a fun one. The cast ensemble is great. The visual effects are awesome. The music score by Tomandandy is beautifully done. One of the best in the series. The climax delivered one awesome fight scene. I cant wait to see where the sixth movie goes.

review_title: Few entertaining scenes but overall a really really dumb zombie/action movie
review_detailed_main:
Okay so Paul W.S. Anderson really didn't seem to care much about this franchise as long as it's a cash in. And it really really shows with this one. Cause out of every "Resident Evil" movie in this franchise which is based on a video game series has almost nothing to do with the games. The plot is the most stupid one in this franchise and there is just way too many obvious plot-holes. In fact some of the audiences walking out even couples were talking about how dumb this movie is. Yeah for how dumb this movie is, it does have few entertaining action parts. But by giving credit for that would be complimenting all of Michael Bay movies. Just throw in bunch of actions and explosions that is incoherent to the story kinda deal. This time it introduces three new characters from the video games to this movie. But they just have the same name and similar attire and that is it. The characteristics and mannerism of these characters are so different from the video games. They even look very different. Leon S. Kennedy is suppose to be this cocky, reserved and sarcastic character that does everything it takes to get the mission accomplished and yet he is likable and cool. But in this he comes off as sorta a doofus and a bit too tall to be Leon. Ada Wong is suppose to be this sly, manipulative character and also sassy and is proficient in what she does. But in this she comes off bland and confused. Her character seemed more like Sherry Birkin. And lastly Barry Burton is nothing like the game character with the slow and yet corny lines he is suppose to have. If they are gonna make a corny movie at least give it to characters that have those characteristics. There is just way too many pointless slow-mo scenes, some critics bash on Zack Snyder for using slow-mo in his movies. I personally thinks he uses well for the most part that actually makes the scene more invigorating. That isn't the case here, and there is pointless kung-fu. The main protagonist Alice uses Kung-fu or whatever on the zombies and than shoots them in the head. Seriously what the crap. And that is not all, the list is almost endless. If your in the mood for a really really dumb zombie movie with lots of action this might be for you. I am guilty to say I was entertained by few scenes. The way this one ends there might be one or two more left in this franchise before it gets rebooted. There is also a partial nude scene with Milla Jovovich like in all of these live action "Resident Evil" movies and it got a bit tiresome.

4/10

review_title: Stupid, Stupid... Did I mention STUPID?

review_detailed_main:
I liked the first Resident Evil film (and even the - much maligned - second instalment). I sat through numbers three and four then promptly forgot them and now tried number five. I kind of wish I hadn't.

Considering it's the fifth in the series, it starts off as if it's trying to reboot itself by being overly clever and bringing back all the dead characters and putting the existing ones in new settings and locations. Maybe I'm just being dim, but it came across as pointless and confusing. Then, when you find out what's really going on, the beginning seems even more unnecessary and serves no purpose other than to fill time.

As most people know, the Resident Evil films are based on computer games. Most films based on computer games get a hard ride for trying to make a story out of a medium which isn't really 'narrative-based.' However, this Resident Evil film seems more like a computer game than most games themselves! If you're playing a computer game, you may expect to play one level set in a desert then the next level set in a city, followed by another level in the jungle. And you'd probably think little of it, as that's how video games work. However, films are supposed to be stories and therefore follow some narrative. Resident Evil 5 doesn't. When the confusing and pointless bits are over, you're left with one action scene after another, simply moved to another location.

The same baddies run at the same goodies and get kicked or shot to death. I know you have to suspend your disbelief when you're watching films, but this one took it too far. No one ever really runs out of bullets, the baddies (despite being an army) can't hit five men standing in the open, women in spandex can outrun lasers and every time anyone enters a new scene (or should I say 'zone?') they have to stand their posing and posturing before finally getting down to (yet more) action.

The film goes on for the usual ninety minutes, however there's only about twenty of those with dialogue in it. Seriously, the script was probably the shortest ever written. Then again... that could be a good thing as the lines are diabolical and the acting even worse.

Then, just when you think it can't stoop any lower, it blatantly rips off Aliens with a 'Ripley rescuing Newt' scene.

There is no story to see here, just action scenes. You might as well play Streetfighter 2 or Tekken on a games console for all the story you get.

I give it 4/10. I would give it 2/10, but the action scenes are well shot and stylish. Paul W S Anderson is clearly a good director who can handle cool visuals. It's just a pity he can't write a good script.

http://thewrongtreemoviereviews.blogspot.co.uk/

It's not as good as the original movie, but much better than the previous for sure. Storywise it's mediocre but not too terrible. Acting and stunts are as typical as they can be for this franchise.

CGI is better than the previous movie, tho the blood effects are still lame af, and the slo-mo bullets are boring when you do it so often.

The best thing about this movie is the SOUND. It hes superb Atmos sound troughout the whole movie, including the opening logos (pretty good show off with the helicopter sounds for the 1st second of logos). The only sounds that i didn't like are the fighting crunchy sounds that were kinda off for me.

Also another minus for the movie is that they stopped using the amazing OST they had in the 1st movie... It was so good but not anymore.

review_title: Is this a Resident Evil movie?
review_detailed_main:
What i just watched is far worse then anything I've ever seen. I'm not a big fan of slow-motion but this movie looks like it was filmed in slow motion, and I don't mean the pace of the movie, it's actually 20% slow motion, bad choreographed fights. There is no plot, sub-plot or any kind of storyline what so ever. The fact that a movie doesn't make sense isn't what bothers me, the very least it must have a beginning and an end (or something).

This movie starts with a slow motion scene and I wanted to walk out of the theater after 10min of slow motion, I'm not kidding, the scene lasts 15min, my wife stopped me and now I wish I walked out. Characters...what characters? I don't even know what I just watched and I was hoping to wake up from a bad dream.

This review isn't very coherent is it? Well expect the movie to be, far far worse. I'm sure this will go down as the worst Resident Evil ever made.

review_title: For the die-hards, it's a keeper!
review_detailed_main: Milla Jovovich never seems to amaze in this movie. More moves brings out the rough side of her. After being neutralized in RE:Afterlife, Alice (Jovovich) continues to bring down that evil corporation. She would later gain a new ally named Ada Wong (Bingbing Li) who wears a similar dress like Alice in the first series. It was nice when Alice has a daughter named Becky (Aryana Engineer, "Orphan") who was involved in an simulation where the undead attack her mom and dad. And of course dealing with the mutants as well. Since the cities were well simulated by Umbrella, The dreaded Red Queen will do everything in her power to stop Alice and her crew. With the return of Luther (Boris Kodjoe) the chances are good. The downside is Rain(Michelle Rodriguez) is a foe. And she really wants to destroy Alice the best she can. The coolest scene for me was the pimped up Rolls Royce Alice drove when she found the team. Slamming that mutant, and driving it to the subway was awesome! This movie was a big turnaround from the last I think. It has plenty of action, a lot of intrigue, and Milla can still kick some serious zombie butt! It has not lost its charm one bit. 3 out of 5 stars

I'm supposed to write at least 10 lines but there isn't much you can say about this.

Save your money.

See something else.

review_detailed_main: From the first seconds of movie starts unknown chaos with no story. Mila is running around some unreal cities and fighting god knows who. Fighting scenes is boring, seen it before and many times. I do not know how actors can join in movie like this, probably an only because of money. I could not even watch this movie to the end. I think only RE1 and RE4 were good others were trash. Even if you watch this movie to the end you not gonna be able to remember what happened here. I just got out of the theater and I am so happy about this movie. I have been waiting since Afterlife for this and they did a fantastic job on Resident Evil: Retribution! This might not make sense to people who didn't start by playing the games as they brought characters from the video game series which I also loved.
