GO SEE THIS MOVIE.

~Joe

Having spawned 5 movies since 2002, all of which have hit the big screen, one could assume that the Resident Evil Franchise is a runaway success. Except, at some point it got diluted and that watering down continued in Resident Evil: Retribution. Sure, even at the young age of 37, Milla Jovovich still has a ton of sex appeal but that only takes you so far.

Retribution brings back some familiar faces including Michelle Rodriguez and Oded Fehr but their parts are wasted and pointless. With an overdose of CGI, explosions and mutated monsters, you wonder what's the point of it all? Yes, Retribution can draw parallels to a video game format where the protagonist has to make it through levels but....so what? Whats, the, point!?

Paul W.S. Anderson has been at the helm of some entertaining features however one can't help but feel that he fell asleep behind the wheel of Retribution or got really lazy. I'm not sure even the most die-hard resident evil fans would be giving this two thumbs up. This is one to miss.

review_title: A Reflection on the franchise itself - All Action, of course
review_detailed_main:
In what is not the last, but is likely the least of installments, we see more of the same and no real movement forward. An epic intro, followed, as always, by Alice's story, or the "previously on Resident Evil", going into another weakly outlined, shallow story, this time tying in more with the very first movie, bringing back multiple characters, albeit some of them are a little different. In a way, "Retribution" is an ode to the franchise itself at that point, and, well, wasn't necessary.

We learn that the situation at the end of "Afterlife" has led to Alice being captured, and tampered with by none other than Umbrella Corporation, which is now solely controlled by the Red Queen, the AI from the beginnings of the franchise. Similarly to the first part, decent portion of events take place inside one of their huge facilities, though it's not claustrophobic no more - the spacious facility is meant for simulations, so various settings are explored. Anderson has tried to make it all fun with use of various terrains, locations, different infected etc., but, again, all in the name of variety in action and eye candy, not story and, frankly, neither atmosphere. I'm not sure if I have seen zombies riding cars and jumping motorcycles before...

The nature of the system of characters don't change, old and new pals, acting cool, come to rescue. Ada Wong existed for exposition and fights, Leon got entirely disrespected as a character, and so were a few other one-function, one-off guys. Characters of "Retribution"don't evolve, except to die or partake in paper thin melodrama. Milla continuously shows devotion to the franchise and Alice, having more range this time around, as one plot line deals with her living the "normal" life as a suburban mom right when the apocalypse starts. I complimented the miniboss in "Afterlife", and they literally pulled the same guy again, this two of them for an action scene. Big scary boys from "Apocalypse" also made second appearances. C'mon guys, to have more of exactly the same wasn't my point. The franchise's standard entertainment value and where it's rooted, in flashy, occasionally even reasonably tense, action sequences, is still alive and well, as is the lack of depth. By the third act, the formula has become a little tiresome, and you find yourself slightly relieved when the climax has passed.

If you're looking for a for an action packed adventure (with a sense of emptiness), this here is a good contender, dramatic, loud, flashy, pointless. My rating: 5/10.

review_title: This sucks way much than previous

review_detailed_main:
"What's with the S&M get up?"

It is hard to figure out how this series is still going, with it's nonsensical plot, and what should be it's strongest point action scenes that are quite boring really.

This time the story follows straight off from Afterlife, The T-virus is still ravaging the world. Alice has been captured and taken to a secret facility, and with the help of some new, old and surprising allies, she must escape from the facility. Looking at the plot the film is quite simple in this addition to the series. But what makes the whole thing quite odd is the motivation for the Umbrella corporation still. As it says in the film they are still experimenting in how to control the T- virus. When you would think they would try to eradicate it by this point, as i imagine profits are dwindling. Also if it is about power with the post apocalyptic landscape if they successfully got rid of the zombies/monsters they would be the most powerful entity in the world still.

As noted in the film quote Alice spends a lot of the film in a nice skin tight S & M style outfit, which reminds of something that did distract me, when Alice is in her cell. How comes Umbrella cannot afford a full gown for her to wear just essentially two pieces of paper connected by string. Then after a power cut suddenly the S & M outfits comes out the wall. WTF. what was it doing there?, is the Red Queen developing some odd tastes? or is the surprising ally still bad and they put it there? i don't know.

I could go on ranting about this film, but the actors do what they can with the script. Also a lot of the action is predictable and boring. But there is some decent action set pieces in there to. In the end if you've seen the others in the series you may as well still see this one. But if you haven't watched the others, don't bother.

review_title: Same mistakes, same pointlessness, same typical Anderson film

review_detailed_main: Hi guys please don't waste your time watching this stupid movie. I was a fan of resident evil series, but not any more. This is a movie shot in a studio alone, not a single frame has seen the real light. Retribution reminded me of kill bill movie, but with worst direction and screenplay. Most of the scenes looked like a video game with background music. I don't know what happened to the director all of a sudden after directing wonderful previous sequences. May be this movie was taken to stop the series without hurting it's fans. After watching this part there will be no more fans. According to me this movie should not have got 5.7 rating. I don't know what is happening to IMDb reviews these days.

Resident Evil: Retribution

The annoying thing about fighting malicious pharmaceutical companies is removing the cotton before doing battle.

Thankfully, the protagonist in this actioner has enough firepower to penetrate the billowy nuisance.

Former Umbrella employee turned mankind's last hope Alice (Milla Jovovich) awakens in an underwater Umbrella base.

There, her adversary (Shawn Roberts) and his aid (Li Bingbing) request her assistance in overriding the supercomputer that has seized control of a plague Umbrella created.

Forced to fight her mind-controlled friend (Sienna Guillory), Alice must also face her daughter from a computer-generated doomsday scenario.

The fifth entry in the video game based franchise, Retribution picks up after the previous film but is more connected to the original.

With a host of returning characters and somewhat of a storyline, Retribution is payback for those sub par sequels.

However, the best way to destroy a possessed supercomputer is to allow your computer- illiterate parent to reset the clock. (Yellow Light)

review_title: I wrote detailed reviews for the first 4 installments

review_detailed_main: I did go see this movie with expectations of it being as good as Afterlife. While I would give Afterlife a 10+, I only gave this a nine. Sure there are some plot holes which could have been filled in. However, The RE series is about effects, action, sci-fi technology, the end of the world, massive explosions, Milla Jovovich as Alice kicking butt. One thing the movie was - unpredictable. I think Capcom have hit the nail on the head with Andersen, he is a great director with a great, intensely vibrant vision. The finale was epic, both story wise and visually, and yes - a fantastic cliffhanger. It is my 2nd favourite movie of the year, first being The Dark Knight Rises. I do think some parts of the end of Afterlife could have been touched on more, been better explained, but at the end of the day, there were more mutants, the zombies were the most creative I have seen yet. This movie is getting mixed reviews but I hope it makes a killing at the box office - I still want a sixth film! GO SEE IT WITH AN OPEN MIND!

review_title: There's More Ugly or Bad than Good.
review_detailed_main: I did enjoy the first four Resident Evil movies, but less with each new installment. Retribution is the same story. As my review's tittle says, there is more ugly or bad than good. First the ugly: 1. Returning stars look like they are not trying anything new with their characters. Especially Jovovich and Rodriguez. The only other movies that were the fifth installment of their franchise or saga where the cast tries this are Star Wars: Attack of the Clones (Yoda fights Dooku), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (a lot of characters), X-Men: First Class (tell an origin story of every character), and the upcoming A Good Day to Die Hard (take John McClane to Russia). 2. Paul W.S. Anderson's directing is at its weakest. Maybe do not need to explain this. 3. There is no character development which I find frustrating because Anderson finally adds Leon Kennedy. Leon is always a character that the fans want to learn more about because he was immediately so cool when he was first introduced in the second game and has never sunk to a level this low. Even in Degeneration and Damnation which are both much better than Retribution. When you do a movie you need to give each character a background story. Bruce Wayne's is a childhood without his parents. Jack Sparrow's is a life as a pirate. All the best characters in movie history have an excellent back ground story. 4. The writers were also very lazy in coming up with the story. Instead of a story that is not cannon with the games, why not give one that is. 5. What ever is going on in Retribution is tough to follow for the first half-hour except for about five minutes. 6. The acting is awful. Awful acting could easily kill a movie while great acting can save it. Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings trilogy needed a great cast and got one. A lot of actors or actresses in video game movies really can not do anything. Retribution clearly backs that up. 7. The movie will not put you at the edge of your seat. You will just wonder when are they going to put you there. Movies like 1964's Goldfinger, 1977's Star Wars, 1989's Batman, 1991's Terminator 2: Judgment Day, 2003's Return of the King, and this year's Dark Knight Rises are great examples of how to put an audience on the edge of their seat. Second the Bad: 1. The movie tells you what is about to happen instead of staying silent about it. Staying silent about what is going to happen in the next few minutes is what made the story ark for other movie franchises or sagas great. Just watch Rise of the Planet of the Apes or Die Hard. 2. The ending. If you just watch it you will see why. And finally the only good that comes out of the movie: 1. The franchise still does not care. It just tries to be fun. I am fine with that. That is what movies are suppose to be. Unfortunately Retribution is no fun. Maybe Anderson should ask Titanic's Oscar winning director James Cameron how to make a follow up better than its predecessor. Two of Cameron's sequels have followed one of my favorite movies. If I have not reviewed them here yet, then when I do you will probably know which movies I am talking about. You may already. So that is both good and bad. 2. The only crew members who do not seem to be getting lazy is the visual effects team. With each new installment they have been getting better and better. They also took advantage of the 3D technology they were given to use. Retribution is the best looking live action Resident Evil. I can not think of any explanation needed here. Final verdict: Resident Evil: Retribution is visually awesome and that is the only redeeming value. Retribution is a soulless and uninspired installment in the most successful (and only one too) video game movie franchise.

It's just like come on every time with this film series, it never ever improves and yet again this movie is a step down from the last outing. We see again a movie full of action, easy to follow yes but fun, my word no, this is awful and that is not a word I have had to previously use on the franchise before. We see this time Alice (Milla Jovovich) fighting yet again, things pick up from where the last film left off, down to the second actually and from then on we see a mass adventure that goes nowhere and only provides glimpses of some decent action choreography that just doesn't mean anything among all the terrible lines spewed out. The man behind this all is Paul W. S. Anderson who is a producer on this film as well as the director and writer, and oh how he screws this one up, a movie I feel just didn't need to be made, or actually, just made well!

Jovovich is typical in her role as Alice and for those who have come to get used to her acting it is same old, really though I do feel the writing makes her feel worse as an actor though. This movie is obsessed with throwing things from the past right back at you and none of them work, it feels like Anderson ran out of ideas within the first 5 minutes and just couldn't be bothered to make something even half decent. The plot is full but flimsy, in fact so full it is that by the end it is breaking off and becoming increasingly run of the mill with every passing second. We see some new faces and some we have seen before but truly none of them work, the villains seem like the shoddiest creation of this movie(the story isn't far off though).

Anderson just doesn't seem to get it that he's not making good movies, sure you can make a few poor one's and they'll blow over eventually, but this is something else. The series started out under average and was poor too but never was it truly very bad but now it is has reached that and maybe it is the annoyance I have for this series or that it just gets worse every time but, I just had to describe this as awful. Let's talk about the technical points and the CGI is OK at times but even that is used stupidly, the sets are something from a weird dream that is also a nightmare and all the time I just felt what a waste of not only production designers, but also of imagination.

I'm not going to rant for nine pages about how I hated this, I'm going to leave it for you to see if you haven't all ready, I know even some like these kind of OTT action movies but this one really does not stand out and can't even rank well among it's not even OK predecessors. I hope one day Anderson can look back on his career and realise this was not a good move, I even hope he can make one film where everyone likes it and says "Hey great job Paul" and not "Remember when you made those dumb zombie movies Paul, they were real bad". So yes, Resident Evil Retribution, a movie that is hard to recommend unless you're either really into zombies or really into Milla Jovovich, and even then there are many better zombie movies out there, and movies with Jovovich in that are also much better.

I got to hand it to Paul w.s. Anderson. Just when I was sure that the plots to these horrible movies couldn't get any more senseless and convoluted; just when I thought that they couldn't crap on the Resident Evil lore and the characters there in more than they already have; they pump out this steaming pile of garbage. The plot (if you can call it that) makes zero sense. The writers of these films have dropped their compass in the woods and are hopelessly lost.

What was wrong with the original video game plot?. RE (the games) 1, 2, and 3's stories were all 10 times better than any of the movies Paul Anderson has made. For the love of all things sacred we need to boycot these films. Future generations will thank us.

review_title: Worst in the series by far
More brain dead than a decapitated zombie
review_detailed_main:
I have a theory about Retribution: Writer/director Paul Anderson lost a bet with Uwe Boll and had to make something that combined the absolute worst parts from the entire Resident Evil series of games

Voice acting as bad as the original. Guns that never, ever need reloading, until the character's plot armour fails. Plot lines that get sold up then go nowhere (Alice's bullet wound). Invisible inventory slots - where exactly was Ada Wong carrying that grapple gun? Intelligent, tool using, team working zombies - the very thing that Umbrella was seeking and failing to create in Extinction.

Nothing in it makes a damn bit of sense. How did Alice get from the Arcadia to the facility? What did the Red Queen need her for anyway? What's Jill Valentine being doing since Apocalypse, why has she gone blonde, and when did she get Goddamn superpowers just like everybody else seems to have developed?

The movie just expects you to suspend your disbelief, hold all questions to the end (and then forget about them), and just watch some sub-Matrix extended slo-mo fight scenes over and over and over again.

All of it I could forgive if at the entire point of the Afterlife / Retribution arc wasn't that Alice was supposed to be de-powered. Well, you could have fooled me. Here she is, flipping and fighting and neck snapping and tearing up armies of zombies and soldiers exactly as before. Anderson the director seemed to have no idea what Anderson the writer was doing.

The plus side is that are some great visuals here and Jovovich is as compelling as ever. But that's it. That's the entire draw of the film. There's simply nothing else here to like, and it's so insultingly mindless that I couldn't kick back and enjoy the spectacle.

Paul W.S Anderson is again back an is once again the director of the new Resident Evil. But this time, the film is a joke, the script is lousy and is to dramatic! The theme song is played every second minutes and you will eventually get enough of this song. But if you've seen the last 5 movies and you wanna see what happens to our hero Alice, you might as well watch it. But do not set your expectations up, make them as low as possible and you can properly get through this ridiculous excuse of an movie. But still the action scenes are great, and is enjoyable an there for i have given the movie 4 stars. But it is not worth 5 stars, because of the silly plot. Enjoy... O:

review_title: Truly frightful horror - for the viewer
review_detailed_main:
As a fan of the "old" RE-games I was always somewhat disappointed by the movies, but the first 3 may just pass as popcorn movies of their own, the 3rd one even having a distinct own atmosphere and being just and enjoyable overall on its own. But from there, this franchise goes downhill lightning-fast. The last movie was already stupid beyond comprehension, the story didn't make any sense at all anymore, and characters and scenes from the RE games were inserted randomly just to create some connection to the games that didn't really exist at all.

But why bash the last RE movie, when this one is so much worse? I truly, honestly believe that it can't get any worse, except maybe if Uwe Boll takes over the franchise. Apart from the Hollywood-Level production values (special effects etc.), the whole "RE: Contribution" movie reeks of lack of competence and interest. The writing and pacing is abysmal, the whole movie is literally just a series of action scenes with no meaningful plot to connect them all; worse, many of those scenes are cringe-worthy and painful to watch, because they're so ridiculous, and many actors are playing like robots on sedatives; I've never seen a worse performance from Michelle Rodriguez; she must have been ashamed to be part of this catastrophe. And don't get me started about Sienna Guillory (Jill Valentine); someone please tell her to get a new job outside the movie business!! The only slightly redeeming factor was Milla Jovovich; while not really a great actress, she performs as good as she can, and is pretty much the only person to convey some actual emotion sometimes.

Don'get me wrong, I like corny, simple action movies in general, but this is just not acceptable anymore. I think Anderson must have been forced at gunpoint to make this movie; that's how I felt while sitting through it. I only watched it to the end to see if there would be at least ONE good plot idea at some point, but to no avail.

Don't watch it if you don't have to, no matter how much of a "Resident Evil" fan you are; this just isn't worth the time.
I tried, I really tried, but found nothing in this movie worth more than two stars.

review_title: I have no idea who this is, but is no longer Resident Evil.
review_detailed_main: It can serve to hang out, but by this fifth installment, this saga has been completely distorted. No one turned away is the basic idea that guided the history of the early Resident Evil games, has moved away completely from the basic idea up to the newest in the series deliveries. The history of the previous 4 films leads this have an exaggerated story, with elements that border on the absurd, and the end is still more illogical and absurd. All it does is grab Andersen loose ideas and scenes of Resident Evil video games, and use it completely out of context and place. I can accept without complaint the first two movies, but since the third part, this film saga has gotten worse. This is no longer worthy to be called "Resident Evil" because not what the hell is, but beyond loose items, this is no longer even close to being true to the series of games that claims to represent.

Well...this was....A.W.F.U.L.... It's almost painful to see what the producer made from the Residente Evil "franchise"...the first one was good, the second, great, the best of them all, the third was the beginning of the downfall, even though I enjoyed it, that "solitude"environment...the fourth, is reasonable, the fight between the big guy with the axe, and Milla (ops, excuse me, Alice) was very good...but this...well, this kills the franchise... There are a few good scenes, for instance, the Tokyo sequel, and the fight between Weskler guys, and the nazy zombies, but still...this is boring as hell... They've killed the interest on this franchise, at least, in cinema (real cinema, at least, because you can always try the "animation"alternatives, that are very good).

In 4 words: Don't Waste Your Time...

review_title: Simply amazing, Awesome cast, and astounding special effects.
review_detailed_main: I first seen the Resident Evil series in 2010, when Afterlife came out, so I watched the entire series...and I must say, I was counting the days when I heard Retribution was coming out. And I Sep. 14 I went with some friends and we had a blast. The movie was amazing, Milla was kick ass as usual. and you can see Paul Anderson's touch in the film. I loved it, nonstop action and gorgeous babes kicking ass....Retribution was made as a Action/Horror film, so all you people complaining that there's not enough character build up and blah blah, shut up!, its not a drama and its prob. not gonna win an Oscar, but if your a RE fan, you'll simply love Retribution! 15/10 :) enjoy

review_title: Please, stop doing this trash with amazing title "Resident Evil"
review_detailed_main:
Greetings from Lithuania.

I'm a big "Resident Evil" game fan. To me, first three "Resident Evil" games and later fourth were among the best video games ever. I've played first two games hundreds of times. And then the movie came out. The first "Resident Evil" film wasn't bad, neither it was good. The second part probably was the best, only because it was the closest to the material. Now with the fifth installment i can safely ask - why in the name of fans they are putting title "Resident Evl" in the front of this movie and series? It's NOT the "Resident Evil" i know. It's just MIla Jovovich every two years playing some kind of character in some kind a world that somehow supposed to be relative to Resident Evil game franchise. But it's not. They (creators of movie franchise) are just putting names from game series in to a movie series without ANY connection at all. In this fifth movie i saw a character of Barry, from the first "Resident Evil". I recognized him just from his costume. But so what? How is he connected to this movie nonsense series at all? "Resident Evil" the one i love became some kind a creepy family business (you know what i mean) for a B list star (once an A list star) and a shitty director. Please, STOP. I really hope and inside of me i really believe that one day some good movie maker will reboot this mess that is done now, like Ch.Nolan rebooted Batman. I believe that in rebooted series characters from the game will be CHARACTERS, not just the names thrown in for the marketing purposes. I hope that in rebooted series there will be plot. God, i so hope that after seeing that movie in a theater i will walk out and say, "you know what, now that was a great "Resident Evil" movie. Hey, can you even remember that trashy series now?"

These movies do the RE games no justice. Absolutely awful. The characters and scenery is atrocious. They try so hard to be like, The Matrix with a movie that should strictly be survival horror. Plus, the writer/director put his wife, Milla Jovovich in EVERYTHING! I'm actually tired of seeing her face. Alice this, Alice that. He should have killed off her character a long time ago. She's not even a real character in the game. Paul Anderson is garage, and so is Milla. Why they keep giving him work is beyond me. Don't waste your time giving this movie a watch. Seriously, there's much better movies out there.

I was stunned at how awesomely bad this sequel is. Of its 117 minute running time, it featured maybe 3 minutes of dialogue, and they were badly written. The rest of the film was filled with battle sequences that, while fairly visually impressive, are ridiculously long, tedious and, once it passes the ten minute mark for one battle, very boring. Shoddy script, appalling miscasting of Johann Urb(-a-derp) as Leon, and an extremely weird performance from Li Bingbing as Ada, as it appears they've overdubbed every single one of her lines in post-production. Even given the relatively low expectations of the Resident Evil films, this one is a dud. Awful, awful, awful.

review_title: More boom boom, less blah blah
review_detailed_main:
This is basically how I would summarize the fifth installment of the decadent Resident Evil franchise. This is a series of movies that I have yet to fully watch, but at times it seems frustrating to watch good source material poorly used. From some parts that I saw from the original,I think that might be the best. After that I've also seen a bit of Apocalypse, all of Extinction, and have yet to see Afterlife. So far the things I liked about these movies are some of the action, Milla Joviovich in general and for the better part Extinction (Saw it when I was younger). As far as Retribution goes, one shouldn't expect any more than what we get as a standard in Hollywood: All boom boom, no blah blah. On a side note, the ending kind of had me a bit interested, but had this franchise had any sort of impact on me in the last few years, and I would have been pumped. The only reason I don't give this one is because of Milla's physique (Sue me, I'm male) and a generally good set up for the upcoming final movie in the saga.

Rating: 3/10

Mostly underrated by reviewers who don't have a clue what 'Resident Evil' is. I'm a big fan of the game and that's the origin to all movies, if you are not a fan of the game for sure you won't like the movie. We were playing the game, waiting for an animation, cinematic scene to show to enjoy watching it. Now that we have a complete real life movie, you would complain? In contract to other movies, the more they release the better it gets. I liked the last 2 movies (after life & retribution) more than the 3 previous ones. More familiar faces, characters were introduced and the intensity of the action has increased. I did not realized those 2 movies were done while watching until i saw the ending already! So please stop rating or reviewing, if you don't have an idea what's Resident Evil is all about because you would never judge the movie right.

As a huge fan of Resident Evil games, this movie (and all the others) are a big disappointment. First of all, there's Alice. I Mean, who the hell is she? Some kind of a freak with zombie super-powers who should never be in any of the movies. IT'S A RESIDENT EVIL MOVIE, THE FANS WANTS TO SEE OUR BELOVED CLAIRE, JILL, CHRIS, LEON, ETC AS THE PROTAGONISTS, NOT HER!

OK, all of those were present in the last movies, but they were nothing but supporting characters for Alice. Ada for example couldn't be worse: in the video game series she is a mysterious woman, full of herself, with legendary abilities, in the movie, she's no more than a Chinese little girl who barely got out of her 18's. Leon is just a selfish coward who wanted to let everybody die to save himself, Barry is a weirdo, and there's Jill.. the worst character of them all, who became a umbrella hybrid or anything like that. And I'm still trying to forget that shameful presentation of Claire in the third movie.

Of course they're all there to watch Alice save the day and could be easily replaced with any nobody in the plot. Maybe that's what's went too wrong with those movies: they insists with Alice, when all of the fans wants her far away as possible and our beloved video game heroes taking the action as they did in the games.

3 stars because the fighting scenes were definitely nice, and I wouldn't mind paying attention to the story, because it's simply one of the worst that I've seen in a long time.

It's actually great that this movie revenues didn't payed the costs, maybe they'll have to listen to fans and finally make a decent, loyal to the game sequence, or to finish this horrible series, let the zombies (are they still zombies anyway?) take over the world.

review_title: Truly Disappointing; one step above direct-t- video

review_detailed_main:
Straight from the sour success of capturing the freighter Arcadia and the incoming attack by Umbrella Corporation forces, Alice (the undying Mila Jovovich) is torpedoed straight back into ultimate undead warfare. After capture by the Red Queen, Alice finds herself locked down in an underground (or rather under-ice) research facility, which tests outbreak scenarios on cloned populations, despite having almost no safeguards whatsoever, which would allow for the situation control. Albert Wesker (Shawn Roberts) reappears to switch allegiance to humankind, disabling Alice's prison and sending in Ada Wong (Bingbing Li) to assist with her escape. Meanwhile reinforcements come from above in the shape of Leon S. Kennedy (Johann Urb), Barry Button (Kevin Durand) and the ex-basketball star, current special op Luther West (Boris Kodjoe). Together they must break Alice out from this deadly complex...

Despite all its faults and dumb-downed premises the Resident Evil franchise has always been - for lack of a better word - entertaining, even captivating. Action sequences performed with flair, whilst the endless charisma of heroine Alice makes for easy and endlessy appealing watching. Essentially the best video game features on offer with an ever-expanding story and universe to get engulfed by. Nonetheless this time Paul W.S. Anderson fails to follow through on the base promise, basically throwing everything at the audience, except for the kitchen majini. In an attempt to out-explode and out-kill previous outings everything is bigger, stronger and more visceral, but lacks similar charisma and deathly charm. Instead of one Executioner Alice now has to face two, while lickers have seemingly grown in size, stature and durability. Anderson basically rehashes almost all that worked in previous parts, mixes in a bit of "Aliens" iconography, then fails to build it around anything resembling a script. Whereas the action sequences and fights (apparently now heavily inspired by muay thai) are consistently top grade, the same cannot be said about the cast, who apart from several passing grades, fail to deliver quality, instead churning out leaden and uninterested performances. Much probably owed to the lack of plot, which unlike the previous stories always felt focused on an intriguing ordeal.

From my side I also sincerely despise the fact that Red Queen has been converted into a malicious computer AI, whilst her ulterior motives set out in the original were logical, obvious, even if homicidal. That said there is still chance to sensibly disclose the logic behind Red Queen's current actions, but this episode in the realm of Resident Evil severely limited faith in Anderson and his overall outlook.

review_title: Perfect example of what you.... SHOULD NOT DO !
review_detailed_main:
Resident Evil, a mythic name in survival horror turn into a brainless action movie... Well this is basically what you have here. If the first couple of movies took liberty and replaced our beloved heroes with a poor character without savour, at least they tried to remain close to the source material. Then the third one was a mess and the rest lost any appeal.

This movie dosen't have any plot, its basically a "go from point a to point b" type of movie, pretty much like dragging a middle movie action sequence during an hour and a half... It pretty much feel like they didn't know what to do for the next movie, so they had Paul Anderson's kid or nephew or whatever write something that he tough would look cool on cam... It feel like it. Characters are randomly pop out of nowhere, are nothing except costumes from there video game counterparts, enemies have pretty much the same treatment and this movie just feel like a big mess.

If you like the video game, stay away from this movie, its basically like hearing your little sister that have absolutely no talent for singing trying to sing a song you like... it may be the same tune, but damn it has nothing to do in common with it.

If you don't like the game, don't care about story and just want good visual effects and action scenes, well it may suit you, cause its the only thing good about it.

The most ridiculous game to movie transfer ever made! I mean, the previous movies were bad, but this.. Holy Cow!! This was just a quick mix of the video game characters with lots of effects, but still crappy ones. Bad written story, most of the scenes didn't make any sense. I am so disappointed with P.Anderson. I had higher expectations of him as a director but he totally ruined it.I gave it a 2/10 cause i just like the title: Resident Evil. I get it though, Mr Anderson choose actors with more familiarity to him. But still, the result is terrible. Zombies sprinting and shooting while riding bikes.. OK.. I mean, there are so many downsides with this movie that i forgot most of them. And that is a good thing! Trust me!

review_title: Every time i watch Resident Evil, i expect it to get better or at least be as good as the first but every time i get disappointed.

review_detailed_main:
So what's this film about? you might ask, well there's girls and there's guns.. lots of them, and zombies.. lots of those as well.

If you've decide you've wanted to spend your time watching a zombie franchise on it's fifth sequel then your standards are quite apparent and as such you will not be disappointed by the high levels of girl on zombie violence.

But maybe this isn't enough for you, maybe you require an involved storyline dealing with the complexities of human nature.. as previously stated you've decided to watch the fifth sequel in a franchise just be glad that you have this kind of time on your hands.

OK, the story is got to get from A to B, but oh know, zombies! Where's the tension there? ..did I mention they've only got two hours till the bomb explodes! Oh yeah there's a bomb!

There's also a heavy dose of leather, soviet zombies and Michelle Rodriguez *breaks a man's heart*.

I've given it a five merely because it's fifth in the series, films like this one transcend ratings.

This is not a movie, is a some kind of experiment for pain. Horrible.

Probably the worst director alive, I don't understand how he gets the gig, also alice is boring as fuck.

review_title: rushed, soundtrack did not fit, but it was fun
review_detailed_main:
I own the the previous four movies on video and will be adding this one around New Year's.

You know what to expect if you are still hanging around as a fan after four blood-soaked, enjoyable movies. This fifth installment into the Resident Evil series reminded me a lot of the fourth Underworld movie in the way that it is constructed.

Some of the acting here is wooden, but the performances during the action scenes make up for it. I was not satisfied at the end, was wanting more and did not want to wait another two years if we are fortunate to experience a sixth.

Even though it felt rushed, the soundtrack is slow in order to give the movie a feeling of epicness. If you peeked at the cast list then it is understandable. An action movie that is slow does annoy me some but not enough to lessen the fun of the action scenes.

We leave behind the horror genre tag and become a sci-fi/action movie so the scares may be gone, but the excitement does not go away with it.

Knowledge of the first and fourth movie seem to be the most important here so you may want to revisit those before watching the fifth.

review_title: The one who played Jill Valentine
review_detailed_main:
I'm sorry but, am I the only one who thinks that the one who played Jill Valentine got her part from sucking the d*ck of someone from high up? I've never, ever seen such an awful performance in my whole life. Even Bollywood actors performs better than her. Every single word that left that womans mouth came out sounding like pure diarrhea. Honestly, I got goosebumps all over my body and actually felt some puke in my mouth while watching this piece of garbage "act".

This movie, this plot, this dialogue and these god awful actors - Its like Asylum and Michael Bay came together to make a lovechild. Wow! I didn't expect much out of this movie to begin with, since this movie franchise has gone bananas with these past movies, but 1/10 has never been deserved so much in IMDb's history. It's a far stretch, but I managed to give it a 3/10 just because Milla Jovovich and Michelle Rodriguez deserves better than this.

review_title: Just like a camera, Point and Shoot......

review_detailed_main: When i think it couldnt get worse than 4th movie this proved me different. The plot is awfull and doesnt make sense at all. I'm very disapointed.

Upon my viewing of Resident Evil: Retribution last night, I was left with an action-packed but ultimately hollow experience.

Lets start with the pros. Resident Evil has action, some of it is really well executed - especially with regards to choreography of fight scenes and encounters with large monsters where 3D was used quite effectively. The film also has plenty of opportunity to have some interesting battles with hordes of zombies however a lot of the film has "opportunity" so that's unfortunately not saying too much.

Okay, now the cons. I have more to say here and don't necessarily have to spoil any of the plot. The film feels very isolated, often like a B-movie. It occasionally remembers that Resident Evil began as somewhat of a horror franchise when it projects a jump scare onto the screen but a majority of it just falls flat. The plot begins as a convoluted mess then straightens up and just turns plain average. The acting is fairly awful with the occasional exception of Jovovich demonstrating distance from people yet implying a longing for closeness. The script is cheesy and zombies feel limited in number which is something unusual for a film franchise notorious for having zombies at its core.

Overall the film is edited and hollow. That's how I can best describe it. Despite being a zombie/monster film, it's surprisingly clean and fuelled by green screen. Though I'll likely see the sequel in the hope it rounds off well - this film feels like a stand in and just more of the same in the series.

4/10

So there's lots of action. Explosion, excitement, boom, bang, kapow and so on.

The story is ridiculously weak. Lot's of the acting is questionable. The script is pretty awful.

Continuity is none existent.

Characters have names for fan service only.

I could go on but I'll just say this is pretty terrible compared to others. I only rate it as high as I have because it has much better CGI than the previous installments.

I'm not quite sure what all the negative reviews are about, except that some were expecting something other than classic Alice and great cgi, this is not a drama or a love story which we have enough of! To me this was a great movie, the script was good,cgi and of course the acting. Mila always comes through and i always love the directors not totally relying on her to carry a movie the other actors were great as well.If you want a crappy love story or some drama which we have enough of yea move on, But if you want an action-packed movie with big explosions blood and some gore with those crazy looking zombie like creatures we all love then by all means sit back and enjoy because this movie delivers.

review_title: Have never reviewed a movie... but I felt compelled.

review_detailed_main:
This barely qualifies as a movie. It's just a 1.5 hours of shooting, fighting and a car chase. There is no story that would make any sense but there is a lot to complain.

The sounds are not badly balanced. But they are ridiculously bad. There is so much shooting that they really should of hired a sound guy who knows what guns sound like. Now we have just random gunsounds for all weapons. A pistol might sound like a pistol and the next round is a rifle sound for no reason. Assault rifle shooting full auto has a random rifle sound in the middle of a burst.

If you hit something the size of an elephant with a car, the elephant might get hurt more - but the car sure would have a huge dent. Not in this "movie".

Somebody really should of shown Sienna Guillory has to shoot a gun. Now she's shooting like she's puching with the weapon.

Most of the movie happens in a holographic joke that they should of left in the 80's Star Trek where it belongs. The holographs are somehow solid but the people are real (or clones) and the scenery can change any time to completely different city. So do half the people get stuck inside walls and other solid objects just appearing out of nowhere when that happens?

That's just a few that come to mind.

Just when I thought it couldn't get any worse with Anderson's Resident Evil film series he proved me wrong. Retribution is downright abysmal. There is nothing redeeming about this movie. The action is stupid and over the the top. The CGI looks awful. The story is paper thing and once again bastardizes main characters from the game series. Previous characters from the last garbage fest movie don't even show up and are just briefly mentioned. This is hands down the worst one in the series so far and considering what the series is as a whole that's really saying something.

I'm usually the first to point out the good points in a bad movie, but I was actually angry while sitting in the theater last night - angry that I had wasted my time and hard-earned money. Sequels (SOME remakes & reboots, too) just for the sake of making sequels have to stop. They're (almost) always terrible. And before anyone mentions 'The Godfather II' or 'Aliens', those were released over 25 years ago - let it go, FFS. This movie just seemed like an excuse to reunite cast members from the first film (for the weakest of reasons), and also to have many, many unnecessary fight scenes that never end. The film's first, second & third acts don't really seem to even come from the same storyline and the film's plot is all over the place. Also, I'm not quite sure how much longer the audience will continue to believe that these specially-trained, martial arts & combat experts (as they all seems to be) can barely hit a single target while shooting at another main character. If you're going to waste your money, spend it on the video games instead.

review_title: It's like a Silly Hindi Action Movie

review_detailed_main: Guys let me tell you this one is really junk, they just did some work that fells like trash. The story of movie is just unwantedly out of the league, at least hire a good storywriter. They just took a story out of trash and just made a movie. This movie is a shame on the name of resident evil.

review_title: One of the WORST Movies I've EVER seen
review_detailed_main:
This movie was absolutely awful. Only 2 things even kept me in my seat: Barry and Ada.

Casting: Awful.

Story: Even more confusing and AWFUL

Relation to the ACTUAL RE series: Not there at all. You can't just add in Character names and hope that fans will be happy. Leon's name could've been Steve and it would have made NO difference to me...no development. AT. ALL.

I'm sure that last movie is going to be, literally, 90 minutes of constant DUBSTEP and Fighting...which will make me feel exactly how Alice did in that STUPID holding cell.

The only thing I'm very happy about is that the next movie will be the LAST by Paul Anderson.

Thank God.

I had much higher expectations from this title thinking maybe after the previous disappointment in resident evil once again I am going to see the glorious days of first movies especially 1 and 2. But, to my astonishing surprise, this one was just another mediocre movie especially in terms of story line. It seemed as if the producers are out of idea and that they have this obligation to exactly following the game without adding any novel ideas to it.

Taking into consideration that I am a fan of the whole series including the games, I am giving it 3 stars. Otherwise 1 would be more appropriate.

I wish to see way better movies on the continue.

I enjoyed this movie. It was different from other parts. The beginning unnecessary rewind scene in which too much VFX was used, was fun to watch. Casting and acting was average. Plot was was little better. Overall, enjoyed it.

review_title: I swear... they aren't even trying anymore.
review_detailed_main:
Without any type of budget or previously awesome monster models.. this movie would be complete and utter crap. The plot is so muddled and stupid that you'll be rolling your eyes the entire film in disgust. The creators of this series no longer care about releasing a good story, it's all about money now.

If you are a fan of the resident evil series.. which I certainly must question how any one can be anymore... don't even bother with this one. The return of previous cast members means absolutely nothing, and in fact you begin to hate them as the mere notion that this film has any connection to previous resident evil movies is enough to drive you to the brink of insanity.

Pathetic. Stupid. Never again.

I almost walked out from this one. It was almost a B movie. The effects were like the only good parts of the movie. The previous Resident Evil movies were a lot better than this one. I frankly found this one to be quite disappointing. Too many scenes with blazing guns. The actors lines were often dry and amateur sounding. I almost feel sorry for the actors who probably may have thought that this one was not like the previous movies. There were hardly any zombie scenes either in this one. I could never watch this one again. I supposed this movie is more for like younger teens and video game addicts. Its really just a shooter. This one is not worth watching at the cinema. Wait for the DVD version if you wanna see it instead.

After watching the first four instalments, I don't really see any need for this film to exist. It just rehashes bits and bobs from previous RE movies, and adds absolutely nothing to the series. I think I'm being generous with two stars...

I clicked on the option that there's no spoilers here, but to be honest, this movie spoils the franchise itself. The only reason you'll like this movie is if the "lickers" were your favourite thing about the game, and it's debatable as to whether they actually make his worth watching.

review_title: The worst film of the franchise
review_detailed_main:
¨ My name is Alice, and this is my world. ¨ Resident Evil was in my opinion the best movie adapted from a video game thanks in most part to Milla Jovovich. Almost all other films have failed to make the transition from video game to film, but there was something special about seeing this heroin fighting off the undead. What began as a horror film eventually turned into a nonstop action film in the following sequels: Apocalypse, Extinction, Afterlife, and now in the fifth one Retribution. I enjoyed some of the previous sequels although to a much lesser degree than the original. I was just fascinated with Jovovich's character, Alice, that I didn't mind that Resident Evil was quickly turning into an action franchise. Finally in Retribution I realized it was just getting too old and mind numbing. I was really disappointed with this film, although my expectations were lowered by the previous sequels. I was hoping that since some of the characters from the original film would be back that the film would go back to the horror genre, but instead it was much more action packed than the rest with so many characters that I just lost interest in the film. My love for Alice diminished after the first 30 minutes of Retribution and I was hoping the film would end soon. The acting in this film is terrible (not that it wasn't in the other sequels, but it is even worse here) and I really didn't enjoy any of the characters. The plot was also very hard to follow at first and I feel that every time a new film starts they forget about everything that was left untold in the previous films. It's as if they want these films to stand on their own, but they keep on raising questions and then never answer them.

Retribution picks up right where Afterlife ended with Alice (Milla Jovovich) and the few survivors from the apocalyptic world in the Arcadia ship being attacked by planes from the Umbrella Corporation with Jill Valentine (Sienna Guillory) commanding them. During the attack Alice manages to bring down one of the planes before jumping off the ship to the water. After she awakes we see her locked up somewhere in a clandestine Umbrella facility where she is continually interrogated by Valentine who is receiving orders from the Red Queen (a computer that controls the entire Umbrella system). Then all of a sudden there is a security breach and Alice is able to escape and finds she's in Tokyo or some place similar. She is attacked by the virus infested people and manages to make her way back to the facility. Here she is helped by Ada Wong (Bingbing Li) who tells her she has been held captive by the Red Queen and that she has helped her escape. She also lets Alice know that she was still in the facility and that she just had entered a simulation of Tokyo created by the evil corporation to train their soldiers. Ada works for Alice's enemy, Albert Wesker (Shawn Roberts) who claims to be helping her since he needs her help after having lost control of the corporation. Albert has also sent some other men to rescue her including Luther (Boris Kodjoe), Leon (Johann Urb), and Barry (Kevin Durand). Together they will have to find a way to survive the undead and escape the facility, although the Red Queen has some surprises along the way: Rain (Michelle Rodriguez) and One (Colin Salmon) have been cloned and also receive orders from the Queen.

Despite being introduced to some of the old characters, in Retribution the Redfield brothers and K-Mart are left out along with several other plot elements. The main problem I had with this Paul W.S. Anderson film was the over abundance of action and characters. It was just too much for me. The best part of the film happened in the beginning in a scene that reminded me a lot of the original and had me fooled it was returning to the horror genre. It was a scene involving Alice waking up in her suburban home along with her daughter Becky (Aryana Engineer) and her husband Todd (Oded Fehr). Everything seemed like it was back to normal until some zombies began invading their home. Those 5 minutes where the most suspenseful and intense moment of the film. I just wished the film would've stayed that way instead of returning to the action packed scenes with hardly any scares or dialogues. It was just one action scene after another and nothing new was added to this film. I was really disappointed with Retribution and it will probably be among my list of the worst movies of the year.

http://estebueno10.blogspot.com

review_title: Not as bad as others in the series, but series does need a serious reboot.

review_detailed_main:
I was disappointed.

The movie itself is very closely modelled on the idea of playing a video game: in other words - a big action scene, culminating in the destruction of some kind of 'boss', followed by a short of cutscene that works as a minimal interjection of plot. Rinse and repeat about 10 times and thats the film in a nutshell.

It did not appear really that much effort was put into the 'story' elements of the film, and most of the emphasis is on action sequences, which are all 'ok'.

I really did not feel engaged by this film. If you like a lot of spectacle and not much else, you may find it entertaining. I kept finding myself bored by the lack of plot.

Even the 'creatures' were exact rehashes from previous films in the series. Nothing new or interesting there.

There was also a particular male character - played by Johann Urb - whos acting was so wooden that it was actually distracting from the story.

The film makers knew they could cash in on this one without making too much effort to think about what they could contribute to the story or the character, and thats exactly what they did.

Don't bother, unless you are a die-hard fan.

review_title: Another Pointless Sequel In An Already Mediocre Franchise
review_detailed_main:
Let me start off this review by saying that i've never been a huge fan of the Resident Evil films. I hated the first one, the second one was so bad it was fun to watch, the third film was decent, and the fourth I actually had a fun time with. The main reason I watch these films are because I am a huge fan of the games and I always thought the action sequences were actually well done in these films. With each film in the series getting a little better, I figured that i'd give Retribution a shot in hopes that it would be similar to Afterlife with over-the-top action and amazing 3D effects.

Unfortuantly, Resident Evil: Retribution is a step backwards in a franchise that was never that good to begin with and while it may not be the worst film in the franchise, it's easily the most pointless. First off, the tagline "Evil Goes Global" and trailers for the film are incredibly misleading. They presented the film as if it was going to be Alice and the rest of group traveling around the world fighting zombies and taking down Wesker. The film is actually about Alice and a team of survivors trying to escape an underwater located Umbrella Base while they go through simulations of locations around the world such as Tokyo and New York City. I couldn't help but feel ripped off by the end of the film as I expected something totally different and got something that just seemed rather lazy.

Before I go anymore further into the negative aspects of the film though, I do want to mention some positive things about it. The action sequences in the film are once again really well filmed. While Paul W.S Anderson may not know how to direct a film as a whole, he knows how to shoot action. The action sequences in the first act are excellent and the climax scene had me on the edge of my seat. While I would say the film is non-stop action, the middle section of the film consist of generic shoot-em up scenes that are just not that entertaining or fun to watch. As a result, the film ends up feeling dull from this point up until the climax. On another positive note, the film is well paced and moves super fast so we never feel too tortured by even the dullest of scenes. It also provides a video game like feel to the film which is always a nice touch. Speaking of the video games, I have to admit it was pretty cool to see Leon in the film as he is my favorite character in the games.

However, thats where the positives end for the most part. Back on the negative aspect, as I said before, there is almost no plot in the film and it's more of just a set up for a bunch of action sequences. I wouldn't have minded this as much if all of the action sequences were as equally entertaining instead of falling back on lame shoot-em-up scenes by the halfway point. I've also got to say that this film is incredibly stupid, and I mean stupid! I know that these are turn-your-brain-off action movies, but I just couldn't get over how incredibly stupid this movie was! Almost nothing made sense and the fact that Alice spends half of the movie trying to save a little girl that she finds in one of the simulations who serves no purpose what so ever and isn't even a real person. It was probably one of the worst plot devices i've ever seen in a movie and all the action sequences could've been set up just fine without her, in which would've resulted in a much less mind-numbingly stupid movie. Now i've never been into the story of this series, but the fact that this movie had none and did nothing to advance the progression of the already thin story in the previous films had me wishing they would've. While watching, it's hard to not feel as if Anderson and Jovovich have finally grown tired of this franchise (as they should've a long time ago). And while nobody goes into these films expecting good acting, it's worth mentioning that the acting here is by far the worst in the series. On a side note, one thing that also got me into the theater was the 3D effects. After Afterlife and it's amazing 3D, one would expect Retribution to at least be on par with it's 3D effects. Unfortuantley, the 3D here is rather mediocre. It doesn't add much depth to the film at all and while there are plenty of gimmicky moments, none of them pop out like they should. This lackluster 3D effects are most likely a result of Anderson switching to using Red Epic Cameras (a cheaper brand of 3D technology) instead of the Fusion Camera System that was used for Afterlife. This was most likely done for budget reasons, but at the expense of the 3D technology for the film.

Even for fans of the franchise, Retribution is a hard film to recommend because it does nothing to advance the story that many of the fans enjoy and is nothing more than just 90 minutes of filler for a 6th film in the series. What saves it from being downright terrible are the action sequences. Judging by the ending, there's not doubt that a 6th film is on it's way. Lets just hope that the series ends there because Retribution is only more proof that this franchise should've have never gone as far as it has.

review_title: So Bad, So Dumb and So Unnecessary
review_detailed_main:
For the life of me, I can't understand the purpose of this movie other than to be a shameless money-grab. This movie makes absolutely no sense in the overall plot line of the series. It's basically just a giant live action video game. It's also a shameless knock off of Aliens.

Unconditionally, the stupidest installment in the franchise.

While the acting, action and special effects are the same as previous installments in the series, this one simply makes absolutely no sense whatsoever in the grand scheme of things. It's basically just a huge, misguided "appeal to the fans and bring back old characters" effort that really doesn't work.

Some have described as a giant cut scene... I think that's being generous.

3.5 stars rounded down to three, completely unnecessary to the series and not really recommended. The fact that it's free on Netflix is the only reason why someone should watch it.

This film essentially picks up where the last movie "Resident Evil-Afterlife" left off with "Alice" (Milla Jovovich) fighting a desperate battle aboard the old cargo tanker "Arcadia." Totally outnumbered and outgunned, Alice is eventually captured and upon regaining consciousness, wakes up to find that she is being held captive in an underground facility with her former ally "Jill Valentine" (Sienna Guillory) now working for the "Red Queen" (Megan Charpentier) and attempting to brainwash her into compliance. During this process, her other enemy "Albert Wesker" (Shawn Roberts) hacks into the computer mainframe which allows Alice to escape from her cell. She then meets one of Wexler's agents named "Ada Wong" (Bingbing Li) who explains that they are also at war with the Red Queen's Umbrella Corporation, and suggests that they team up to fight their common enemy. To that effect, Wesker has sent a small commando team to help extract Alice from the Red Queen's clutches. The problem is that both Jill and the Red Queen have an army of computer enhanced zombies at their discretion and plan on throwing everything they have within the facility to prevent their escape. Now, rather than reveal any more, I will just say that, once again, the director (Paul W. S. Anderson) discarded tried-and-true cinema techniques like horror or suspense and decided to utilize action and CGI instead. No real plot. No real acting. Just action and CGI--and lots of it. On that note, I must admit that the CGI is quite good and as such the film wasn't a total waste of time. Even so, in the hands of a good director the final product could have been really outstanding. Unfortunately, that just wasn't the case and I have rated this movie accordingly. Slightly below average.

review_title: Resident Evil: Retribution... A Really Good One

review_detailed_main:
Resident Evil: Wrestle-bution With Zombies

The best words that could describe this movie: Wrestling + Karate + Boxing = Milla Jovovich

The title of the next movie (According to the end of the movie):

Resident Evil: the Zoo of Dinosaurs

the best thing about this movie is the eye-catching costume design and visual effects. nothing else.

we need some pro gamers to direct this movie.
There were a lot of good ideas in this, but the lack of a story really drags this down.

review_title: Resident Evil 5: Retribution seeks in a distant past some references to build its plot, but the excess of action tires the audience
review_detailed_main:
The best feature of the feature film by Paul W. S. Anderson offers are references to games. The narrative is built to look like a game. There are stages - each set in a different country, with different bosses and enemies for each - virtual transitions, new weapons or powers unlocked at each new stage, among other elements taken directly from video games. The whole movie has the look of a Playstation game, from photography, to costumes and characters from the game universe. In addition to Alice and Jill Valentine, join the franchise old acquaintances from the games, who had never shown up in cinema. Ada Wong, Leon S. Kennedy and Barry Burton are examples of this, gaining space in the films to the delight of fans of the franchise.

After so much running and running, it's really hard to get a sense of where our protagonist Alice (Milla Jovovich) really is, but suffice it to say that her quest for revenge against the Umbrella Corporation continues unabated, which here imprisons Alice in a kind of complex that, you see, it simulates experimental realities that are very similar to the game phases that need to be won in popular electronic games. Once again, Alice will have help to escape this challenge, as she will come across (in a clever trick of the script) with the return of some familiar faces of the franchise.

Right away, "Retribution" shows what it came from: a burst of visual effects. Carrying on the legacy of "Afterlife", 3D is widely used. However, it seems that Paul Anderson learned from the exaggerations of the previous film. The strategy of making things "fly" in the audience's face is used more modestly and when it is done, it has a less obvious impact than it did in the previous film. Slow motion is also used more intelligently, at times when the effect is needed. The opening scene is unusual and has a very positive effect - it's like we're inside Alice's mind, trying to piece together a recent memory. Not only does the feature film start right where the previous one left off, it explains the entire heroine saga so far. If you haven't watched the other films, you won't be parachuted into history, even if it's not that complex. It is the first clue to Anderson's tendency to relocate in "extra-film" everything - contextualization, exposure - that does not refer to the action itself. In one scene, where Jovovich teaches Michelle Rodriguez how to use a gun, she says, "It's like a camera, you just point and shoot." This phrase synthesizes Anderson's work - a vision of cinema at once simple and simplistic -, which treats diegetic space as the domain of action and action alone.

Perhaps it is thinking about this that Paul W. S. Anderson promotes in this fifth film the return of a figure that was absent since the first feature, the Red Queen artificial intelligence. The sinister computerized little girl (now played by Megan Charpentier) is not only the main element of the "extra-film" in Retribution, giving information that situates and moves the plot, but also behaves like the master of the game, triggering scenarios and bosses. -stage every mission from Alice and her friends. The fact that Retribution is set entirely in an Umbrella test facility, from which the heroine needs to flee, obviously gives the film a game face, but it is more in Anderson's direction choices than in the script itself that this kinship is established in fact.

Despite the crazy proposal to conduct the story in an underground Umbrella complex used for simulations, the plot actually makes sense. Unexpectedly, the installation's existence, construction and purpose are explained, a rarity in Anderson's scripts so far (with the exception of the first). In the end, the idea of "global evil" (which theoretically has been around since RE3: The Extinction) is somewhat exaggerated. Even if we visit Tokyo, Moscow, New York and Raccoon City, the changes of scenery are not so relevant. In the sequences where the characters are in these cities, the location itself doesn't seem to make a difference, since the biggest interaction is not with the environment, but with the creatures. The proof of this is that the sequel in Raccoon City, with the simplest scenario, is one of the most interesting. Meanwhile, in NY the Axemen steal the show and the giant Licker makes you forget you're in Moscow.

Once again, the filmmaker explores as much as he can the beauty of his wife, Jovovich, placing her in situations, clothes and poses that evoke only mildly masturbatory images for the male teenage audience (but without showing too much, unfortunately). The promise of a human Alice is definitely fulfilled. Finally, Milla Jovovich showed a more interesting, more empathetic character than the "killing machine" of previous films. In "Afterlife" Alice was supposed to show her human side after losing her powers, but all that was shown were sequences of impossible feats, not worthy of mere mortals. Yes, Alice from "Retribution" is still the badass who kills zombies with impossible stunts and unnecessary explosions, but the fifth feature shows that there is a woman there inside that thick shell. This impression is not restricted to scenes with "Suburban Alice", but also with "Real Alice" and using a child to bring out the sentimental side of the character was an excellent strategy. What is strange is this human side awakened by Becky not causing any kind of commotion in Alice when she sees her friends who died at Umbrella's hands being used as clones to hunt her down.

While there is better development for Alice, again, the secondary characters are completely smothered by her presence, especially when considering Leon and Barry. Requests to bring the character from RE4 to the movies were finally granted, but the script doesn't allow the character to be explored, known and become empathetic. Still talking about game characters, Ada Wong is definitely a standout. Li Bingbing manages to get very close to the spy, despite lacking sensuality. The character is better constructed and explored by the script than Leon and Barry, mainly because of constantly sharing the scene with Alice. However, at a certain point in the film, Ada loses space and prominence - we practically forget that bitch in the red dress is one of Albert Wesker's main agents. While Ada is a surprise, Jill is a disappointment. Sienna comes in as the featured villain, which supposedly makes her an important character in the plot, but what has happened to her since RE2: Apocalypse is unknown. When and how was she captured? Since when is it controlled? Sienna had said in an interview that, like Jill from RE5, she would be aware of her actions while acting against her will. At no point was this shown. Luther could have died in "Afterlife", as we came to think, since his participation is insignificant. Chris and Claire are named, but after the battle in Arcadia and the destruction of the Umbrella compound, I'm not sure how Paul Anderson will explain a possible return of the two to the plot.

The clones' proposal, which was used as a rather lame justification for bringing Michelle Rodriguez, Oded Fehr and Colin Salmon into the cast, was passed over. Wesker is now, we might say, a former villain. Despite not showing any clear intentions (again, the script fails to explain a relevant point), the character is determined to bring Umbrella down and, as in Umbrella Chronicles, put an end to the Red Queen supercomputer. Now, the girl is a kind of Skynet, who controls Umbrella on all its levels - and hates the human race? This is likely to be the loose end of Alice's journey in the next film.

A lot can be said about Resident Evil 5, unless it's a boring movie. The action scenes start right in the opening credits - with a bombastic air raid sequence. It's gunfire, zombies, huge monsters, races and car chases, all at high speed and noise like action fans love so much. With that, any kind of development in relation to the central characters is left aside so that there is more space for the adventure. In other words, don't expect to understand who Alice is or who are her friends. They are just instruments for the action to run as smoothly as possible. Again abandoning zombies for much of the narrative, this new chapter in the Resident Evil saga continues what the previous ones had been doing, increasingly moving away from the undead movie label. Here, the villains are Umbrella and the freaks created by the corporation. Zombies are a small part of the whole. Interestingly, brain-eaters are all the rage lately and it even sounds strange that Resident Evil producers don't take advantage of this good moment to fill the story with zombies.

During the entire projection, what the director gives us is sequences and more sequences of brawls à la "Devil May Cry" (another Capcom franchise, by the way) that occasionally impress aesthetically, especially due to good 3D photography. But these scenes soon become tiresome and repetitive, not least because the figures we see on screen are extremely two-dimensional, with most serving only to die suddenly or as mere fan service. Well, games can even support unrestrained action because we put ourselves in the characters' shoes, their risk is ours. Here, we have a rather passive experience, with Anderson alternating between unruly slow-motion and abusively fast cuts, like in the final battle in the snow.

Despite having a video game look and being a 3D movie series, Resident Evil 5: Retribution seeks in a distant past some references to build its plot: the open endings, which give clear cliffhangers to the sequel, showing how the Earth is after the last events of the War against Umbrella causes chills and fear of what is yet to come, since the sixth part is confirmed, with the release date already set, with what should be the final chapter. The production of Resident Evil is increasingly worn out, carrying a boredom that increases with each new Alice film against the Umbrella corporation.

review_title: Resident Evil delivers action but little else
review_detailed_main:
Unlike most of the video game based films, the Resident Evil franchise has managed to keep churning them out. While not all are on par with the fun of the original, they each have had something of their own to bring to the table and the fans that enjoy them really get sucked in. The latest installment Resident Evil: Retribution, sported a trailer that seemed to tease the return of previous characters in the series, but does it have anything new to add to the series?

Resident Evil: Retribution follows Alice alongside a resistance movement in her continuing war against the Umbrella Corporation. The latest installment is decent enough, but falls short in a lot of ways becoming the weakest of the series so far. There is a lot to digest here in such a short run time and not all of it works or makes sense. As with most of the films there are a lot of holes in the story, but you let a lot of that go in exchange for the zombie killing action. Here you get tons of action, but still just didn't really have the same vibe as the other films. Jovovich steps into the role delivering the character pretty much exactly the same way she always does, but the same cannot be said for the rest of the cast. Most of them are pretty stiff and feel forced or like they just aren't feeling it. There are plenty of returning creatures and characters, but most of them just didn't feel necessary other than to try and add that missing something. The problem is they don't really do much with most of them and they feel like a wasted opportunity. The location of the film is both good and bad. There were some great opportunities here to do some really cool things with their environment all over the world, but instead it just felt like they really served no point other than to attempt to explain how the T-Virus spread. Yes this info is important, but it could have just been in dialogue without the other aspects, and in some ways it pretty much was which was an overall waste of space. The action was really well done for the most part and there was plenty of it. Easily most of the movie was just gun fights and hand to hand combat which keeps you entertained while suffering through the other nonsense.

Originally it was said that the fifth and sixth film would be filmed back to back and it shows here. This isn't a horrible film, just feels more like filler to something else instead of the standalone films with an obvious more to come ending like the others. If you are a fan of the series be sure to check this out, because it defiantly sets it up for another and if done correctly could be a great cap on a fun franchise.

review_title: How have I made it this far??
review_detailed_main: While I do think the film is more enjoyable than the last two for the fact the plot keeps moving compared to how the others meandered & not to mention a few nice looking set pieces, it's still the same tiring mindless disposable trash we've come to expect at this point. The simulated cities in the facility is so illogical like how does simulation create actual living monsters & things like flammable gasoline? This one has the most characters from the video games but they all feel underdeveloped with nothing to them but to serve fan service to whoever's still watching these. I don't even get why they even bothered bringing Michelle Rodriguez back cuz she feels wasted here compared to her appearance in the first movie. Not to mention the whole cloning Alice concept is just getting real old now. Obviously at this point the box office dollars were talking louder than the scripts bein written.

Too much of everything in this part. There was just no story behind this one. She was like bulletproof standing in open fire. I really like Resident Evil so i hope next part will contain more background. Afterlife had at least some sidestory.

review_title: Visually great...but lacks a a decent story!
review_detailed_main:
I have been a fan of the Resident Evil series since the first movie, i thought it had great potential to cross the video game/movie barrier with strong characters and it's hoards of the undead! Movie gold...Right?

Well, somewhere along the road they lost their way, and this movie unfortunately demonstrates this even more so than the others!

The narrative of this story is so confusing, the characters (including long dead ones) pop up all over the place with no real explanation and the acting is average at best! The inclusion of the 'child in peril' is also completely pointless! The Zombies are a rare sight in this instalment too which i found a great disappointment, and are replaced by poor CGI Lickers and other 'arena constructs' (Hunger Games anyone??)

Personally I think this is the weakest of the series, it's only redeeming feature is that it has some great action sequences which are shot brilliantly. The reverse shots as the film opens are stunning. And Milla Jovovich is on top Ass Kicking form!

If you've seen the rest of the films, this one is worth a look, but if you are new to them, then I wouldn't bother, you will be left wondering "WTF is happening"!

review_title: Don't waste much time on this
review_detailed_main:
Resident Evil: Retribution is directed by Paul W.S. Anderson and stars Milla Jovovich, Sienna Guillory, Michelle Rodriguez, Aryana Engineer, Li Bingbing, Johann Urb, Boris Kodjoe and Kevin Durand in the leads.

The movie is ridiculous and disappointing in many ways and the main disappointment is the cast which is probably the most weakest part of the movie. The movie is undoubtedly spot on for their action scenes and will be a treat for an eyes for the action lovers but apart from action the movie disappoints in a big way.

Apart from Milla it seems that rest of the characters are forced to play the part and seems disinterested. The biggest blot was Michelle Rodriguez who did the acting with a blank face.

Screenplay of the movie was tight and engaging, background music supports the screenplay beautifully.

With pale star cast and their fade acting the movie is certainly a disappointment.

review_title: 3D has rarely ever been that impressive!
review_detailed_main:
Where does this new hype of vanity on the story's and character's profoundity of action movies come from? That's so ridiculous! I am actually not a fan of zombie movies (I've seen around 4 apart from the Resident Evil series), but this movie can not be counted as a regular zombie movie. The intention of this movie isn't telling a story or creating interesting characters that one can empathize with.
